title: Dyadic analysis of compactness on product spaces

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We develop the compactness theory of multilinear singular integrals on product spaces using a modern point of view. The first main result is a compact $T 1$ theorem for multilinear Calderón-Zygmund operators on product spaces. More specifically, we prove that a multilinear singular integral operator $T$ on product spaces can be extended to a compact multilinear operator from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times$ $L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ for all exponents $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ with $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \in(1, \infty]$ and for all weights $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ if the following hypotheses are satisfied: (H1) $T$ admits a compact full kernel representation, (H2) $T$ admits a compact partial kernel representation, (H3) $T$ satisfies the weak compactness property, (H4) $T$ satisfies the diagonal CMO condition, and (H5) $T$ satisfies the product CMO condition. This is a multilinear compact extension of Journé's $T 1$ theorem on product spaces. The second main result establishes the mean continuity of commutators $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ on weighted Lebesgue spaces as above, which can be viewed as a substitution of compactness because the compactness of $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is equivalent to $\boldsymbol{b} \equiv$ constant when $T$ is a non-degenerate bi-parameter singular integral. Our main tools include multilinear bi-parameter dyadic representation, multilinear extrapolation, multilinear interpolation, and Kolmogorov-Riesz compactness criterion.

# 1. InTRODUCTION 

1.1. Motivation and the main results. The current investigation belongs to an extensive research program, which aims to advance our understanding of the compactness of singular integral operators on product spaces. The main reason why we study it comes from three aspects:

- There exists very limited literature concerning the compactness of singular integrals, although the compactness of commutators has attracted a lot of interest recently and many new techniques have been developed, for example, $[3,5,32,33,35,37,61]$.
- There is no a mature theory to research the compactness of bi-parameter singular integrals, except a compactness result by means of projection [6]. In terms of boundedness on product spaces, plenty of remarkable works have been done by $[34,45,46,48,53]$ for singular integrals and by $[30,54]$ for commutators. Extending boundedness to compactness arises naturally.
- What is the precise dyadic structure behind compact bi-parameter CalderónZygmund operators? The rapid development of dyadic analysis has leaded to a much better understanding of one-parameter and bi-parameter CalderónZygmund operators. A modern thinking of singular integrals was given by Hytönen [31], who represented singular integral operators as an average of some natural dyadic model operators. The bi-parameter extension was obtained in $[45,48]$, while sparse domination $[40,42]$ provides a brand new perspective. All these make many problems in the weighted or/and bi-parameter setting more attainable. Inspired by the above, we explore the dyadic structure of compact bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operators.
Before entering into a detailed discussion of the multi-parameter theory, we present the first main result of this paper.

Theorem 1.1. Let $T$ be an m-linear bi-parameter singular integral operator (cf. Definition 3.4). Assume that $T$ satisfies the following hypotheses:
(H1) $T$ admits the compact full kernel representation (cf. Definition 3.2),
(H2) $T$ admits the compact partial kernel representation (cf. Definition 3.3),
(H3) $T$ satisfies the weak compactness property (cf. Definition 3.5),
(H4) $T$ satisfies the diagonal CMO condition (cf. Definition 3.6),
(H5) $T$ satisfies the product CMO condition (cf. Definition 3.7).
Then $T$ is compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in$ $(1, \infty]^{m}$ and $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=$ $\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

To be explicit, let us recall the compactness of multilinear operators. Given quasinormed spaces $\mathscr{X}_{1}, \ldots, \mathscr{X}_{m}, \mathscr{X}$, an $m$-linear operator $T: \mathscr{X}_{1} \times \cdots \times \mathscr{X}_{m} \rightarrow \mathscr{X}$ is said to be compact if $T\left(B_{1} \times \cdots \times B_{m}\right)$ is precompact in $\mathscr{X}$ for all bounded sets $B_{j} \subset \mathscr{X}_{j}$, $j=1, \ldots, m$, i.e., $\overline{T\left(B_{1} \times \cdots \times B_{m}\right)}$ is a compact subset of $\mathscr{X}$.

On the technical level there is no existing approach to our result. First, the compactness of singular integrals originated in [66], where wavelet analysis was used. Even in the bilinear one-parameter situation, the complicated geometric relationship among cubes $I, J, K$ makes it impossible to obtain good localization and then readily parametrize the sums according to eccentricities and relative distances of cubes. Second, although the authors [6] successfully established weighted compactness of linear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operators, the method of projection cannot be applied to the bilinear case. A main reason is that the projection operator $P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp}$ in (2.7) depends on the dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}$ so that the goodness of dyadic cubes in $\mathcal{D}$ cannot be added into the summation, which leads to the disappearance of satisfactory local estimates involving three cubes $I, J, K \in \mathcal{D}$. Third, the theory of sparse domination is missing in the multi-parameter scenario, even for the boundedness. In the one-parameter setting, the authors in [57, Theorem 3.7] obtained a pointwise sparse domination to show weighted compactness. But it requires the weak $(1,1)$ boundedness, which is false in the multi-parameter case.

Our result should be compared with [46, Theorem 1.2], which established the weighted boundedness of multilinear bi-parameter singular integral operator under less restrictive assumptions. Unfortunately, those assumptions are not sufficient to obtain compactness. Generally speaking, multilinear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operators (cf. Definition 3.8) are not compact. To clarify this, recall the bilinear Riesz transform $\mathcal{R}_{j}^{i}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ defined by

$$
\mathcal{R}_{j}^{i}\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right)(x):=\text { p.v. } \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}} \frac{(x-y)_{j}+(x-z)_{j}}{(|x-y|^{2}+|x-z|^{2})^{\frac{2 n_{i} \times 1}{2}} f_{1}(y) f_{2}(z) d y d z}
$$

where $(x-y)_{j}$ is the $j$-th coordinate of $x-y \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}, j=1, \ldots, n_{i}$. Let $\frac{1}{p}=\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}$ with $p_{1}, p_{2} \in(1, \infty)$. Then one can check that
(1) $\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}$ satisfies the full kernel representation (cf. Definition 3.4);
(2) $\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}$ satisfies the partial kernel representation (cf. Definition 3.4);
(3) $\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}$ satisfies (H3), (H4), and (H5);
(4) $\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}$ is bounded from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \times L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$;
(5) $\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}$ is not compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \times L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$.

Indeed, properties (1) and (2) are trivial, and property (3) is a consequence of that

$$
\mathcal{R}_{j_{i}}^{i}(1,1)=\mathcal{R}_{j_{i}}^{i, 1 *}(1,1)=\mathcal{R}_{j_{i}}^{i, 2 *}(1,1)=0=\left\langle\mathcal{R}_{j_{i}}^{i}\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{i}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{i}}\right), \mathbf{1}_{I^{i}}\right\rangle
$$

for all cubes $I^{i} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$, and that $\left(\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2}\right)_{1,2}^{k_{1} *, k_{2} *}=\mathcal{R}_{j_{1}}^{1, k_{1} *} \otimes \mathcal{R}_{j_{2}}^{2, k_{2} *}$ for all $k_{1}, k_{2} \in$ $\{0,1,2\}$, where the adjoints of a bilinear bi-parameter operator are defined in Section 3 and the adjoints of a bilinear one-parameter operator $T$ are given by

$$
\left\langle T\left(f_{1}, f_{2}\right), f_{3}\right\rangle=\left\langle T^{1 *}\left(f_{3}, f_{2}\right), f_{1}\right\rangle=\left\langle T^{2 *}\left(f_{1}, f_{3}\right), f_{2}\right\rangle
$$

Then property (4) follows from properties (1)-(3) and [46, Theorem 1.2]. Additionally, property (5) is a consequence of Lemma 2.17 and [4, Lemma B.13], where the latter implies that bilinear one-parameter Riesz transforms are not compact. Therefore,

the above indicates that one has to strengthen the assumptions in order to achieve compactness of bilinear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operators.

Next, let us turn to commutators. Let $T$ be an operator from $\mathscr{X}_{1} \times \cdots \times \mathscr{X}_{m}$ into $\mathscr{X}$, where $\mathscr{X}_{1}, \ldots, \mathscr{X}_{m}$ are some normed spaces and and $\mathscr{X}$ is a quasi-normed space. Given $\vec{f}:=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right) \in \mathscr{X}_{1} \times \cdots \times \mathscr{X}_{m}, \boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right)$ of measurable functions, and $j \in\{1, \ldots, m\}$, we define, whenever it makes sense, the first order commutator as

$$
[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{e_{j}}(\vec{f}):=b_{j} T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{j}, \ldots, f_{m}\right)-T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, b_{j} f_{j}, \ldots, f_{m}\right)
$$

where $e_{j}$ is the basis of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ with the $j$-th component being 1 and other components being 0 . Then for any $k \in \mathbb{N}_{+}$, we define the $k$-th order commutator of $T$ in the $j$-th entry of $T$ as

$$
[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{k e_{j}}:=\left[\boldsymbol{b}, \cdots\left[\boldsymbol{b},\left[\boldsymbol{b}, T\right]_{e_{j}}\right]_{e_{j}} \cdots\right]_{e_{j}}
$$

where the commutator is performed $k$ times. Finally, for a multi-index $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{m}\right) \in$ $\mathbb{N}^{m}$, we define

$$
[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}:=\left[\boldsymbol{b}, \cdots\left[\boldsymbol{b},\left[\boldsymbol{b}, T\right]_{\alpha_{1} e_{1}}\right]_{\alpha_{2} e_{2}} \cdots\right]_{\alpha_{m} e_{m}}
$$

It is natural to wonder whether the commutator $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is compact for a biparameter singular integral operator $T$, for which the boundedness of $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ was established in $[30,46]$. A recent work [43] gave an interesting result, which asserts that the compactness of $[b, T]_{1}$ is equivalent to $b \equiv$ constant when $T$ is a non-degenerate bi-parameter singular integral. This also indicates that for multi-parameter commutators $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ it is not meaningful to study finer properties of compactness, for example, the Schatten property. In view of these facts above, we would like to seek a property of $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ which is weaker than the compactness but stronger than the boundedness. More precisely, we introduce the following definition.

Definition 1.2. Given exponents $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \in[1, \infty]$ and weights $w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$, a bounded $m$-linear operator $T: L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ is said to be mean continuous if

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0} \sup _{\substack{\|f_{j} \|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1 \\ j=1, \ldots, m}}\left\|\left[\int_{B_{\vec{n}}(0, r)}\left|\left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right) T(\vec{f})\right|^{a} d y\right]^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)}=0
$$

for some $a \in(0,1]$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}, w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$,

$$
B_{\vec{n}}(x, r):=\left\{y \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}:|y-x|=\left|y_{1}-x_{1}\right|+\left|y_{2}-x_{2}\right|<r\right\}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right) f(x):=\tau_{y} f(x)-\tau_{y_{1}} f(x)-\tau_{y_{2}} f(x)+f(x) \\
& =f\left(x_{1}-y_{1}, x_{2}-y_{2}\right)-f\left(x_{1}-y_{1}, x_{2}\right)-f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}-y_{2}\right)+f\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The second main result of this paper is formulated as follows.

Theorem 1.3. Let $T$ be an m-linear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operator (cf. Definition 3.8). Then for any $\boldsymbol{\alpha} \in \mathbb{N}^{m} \backslash\{0\}^{m}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in \operatorname{cmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m}$, the commutator $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is mean continuous from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

The mean continuity is extracted from Kolmogorov-Riesz theorems, which give necessary and sufficient conditions for a subset of a Lebesgue space to be compact (see Section 1.4 below). In the bi-parameter setting, we also establish similar compactness criterion, see Theorems 6.1-6.4, where the last one implies the mean continuity is indeed weaker than the compactness. It is worth mentioning that the form of mean continuity is suitable to weighted Lebesgue spaces $L^{p}(v)$ with general weights $v$ which are not necessarily invariant under translations.
1.2. Outline of the proof of Theorem 1.1. Let us briefly outline how to prove Theorem 1.1. Definitions and notation needed are postponed to Section 3. The core of the proof is a compact $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation as follows.

Theorem 1.4. Let $T$ be an m-linear bi-parameter singular integral operator (cf. Definition 3.4). Assume that $T$ satisfies the hypotheses (H1)-(H5). Then $T$ admits a compact m-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation (cf. Definition 3.12).

It is the first time to introduce a compact dyadic representation in the bi-parameter setting in order to study (weighted) compactness of singular integrals on product spaces. It definitely states the dyadic structure of multilinear bi-parameter CalderónZygmund operators. In contrast to pointwise or integral form domination, such representation has a great advantage to transfer smoothly initial problems to corresponding dyadic problems, for example, commutators estimates and compactness. Theorem 1.4 is based on our previous research in the bilinear case [4] and in the bi-parameter setting [6] (although no dyadic representation is established), and the general framework of multilinear bi-parameter dyadic operators in [46]. Besides, our compact dyadic operators (cf. Definitions 3.9-3.11) are much more complicated than those in [4], and carry much more subtle information than those in [46].

The usefulness of dyadic representation has been shown in other aspects. It can trace back to sharp weighted norm inequalities [55], where a representation was given for the Hilbert transform. Then it was refined in [31] to solve the well-known $A_{2}$ conjecture for general Calderón-Zygmund operators. After that, the bi-parameter extension was given by [48] and the bilinear case was due to [44], while the multilinear multi-parameter representation was established in [45, 46], which can be applied to obtain genuinely multilinear weighted estimates for any multi-parameter CalderónZygmund operators [46] and their commutators. Moreover, the bi-parameter representation in [48] has been used to two-weight commutators estimates [30] and higher order commutators [54]. Recently, the one-parameter representation in [31] has found its application to Schatten class property of noncommutative martingale paraproducts and operator-valued commutators [67].

Having presented a dyadic representation, we have to show weighted compactness of bi-parameter dyadic operators. For this purpose, we establish weighted compactness of the average of the family of dyadic operators, instead of treating one by one.

Theorem 1.5. Suppose that the family $\left\{\mathbf{T}_{\omega}\right\}_{\omega \in \Omega}$ is of the same type for any $\mathbf{T}_{\omega} \in$ $\left\{\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k}, \mathbf{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{1, k}, \mathbf{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{2, k}, \mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{a}_{\omega}}\right\}$ (cf. Definitions 3.9-3.11). Then $\mathbb{E}_{\omega} \mathbf{T}_{\omega}$ is compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{q_{1}}\right) \times$ $\cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{q_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in$ $A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

In addition, we develop Rubio de Francia extrapolation of compactness on product spaces below.

Theorem 1.6. Assume that $T$ is an m-linear operator such that
(a) $T$ is compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(u_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(u_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(u^{p}\right)$ for some $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in$ $[1, \infty]^{m}$ and for some $\vec{u}=\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>$ 0 and $u=\prod_{j=1}^{m} u_{j}$
(b) $T$ is bounded from $L^{q_{1}}\left(v_{1}^{q_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{q_{m}}\left(v_{m}^{q_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{q}\left(v^{q}\right)$ for some $\vec{q}=\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{m}\right) \in$ $[1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{q}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{q_{j}}$ and $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$

Then $T$ is compact from $L^{r_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{r_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{r_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{r_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{r}\left(w^{r}\right)$ for all $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in$ $(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

Theorem 1.6 is indispensable because quasi-Banach compactness can not be obtained directly from the dyadic representation above. Furthermore, extrapolation reduces what we want to unweighted compactness in Banach range, which is quite useful in practice. We should mention that Theorem 1.6 also holds for any $m$ parameter, which can be justified from its proof in Section 8. Its feasibility benefits from our significant work [5], where interpolation and extrapolation for multilinear compact operators were established systematacially. Beyond that, unlike to extrapolation of boundedness [46, Theorem 3.12], the case $p=p_{1}=\cdots=p_{m}=\infty$ cannot be used as the starting point of extrapolation of compactness. For example, even in one-parameter setting, it is very hard to show compactness in the case $p=p_{1}=\cdots=p_{m}=\infty$ because it needs $L^{1} \times \cdots \times L^{1} \rightarrow L^{\frac{1}{m}} \infty$ compactness (cf. [4, Section 9]), which is proved by means of $L^{q_{1}} \times \cdots \times L^{q_{m}} \rightarrow L^{q_{m}}$ compactness for some exponents $q, q_{1}, \ldots q_{m} \in(1, \infty)$ (cf. [4, Section 8]).
1.3. Outline of the proof of Theorem 1.3. Our basic proof strategy of Theorem 1.3 is to use bi-parameter dyadic representation in [46]. This allows us to reduce matters to showing mean continuity of bi-parameter dyadic operators.

Theorem 1.7. Suppose that the family $\left\{\mathbb{T}_{\omega}\right\}_{\omega \in \Omega}$ is of the same type for any $\mathbb{T}_{\omega} \in$ $\left\{\mathbb{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k}, \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{1, k}, \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{2, k}, \mathbb{F}_{\mathbf{a}_{\omega}}\right\}$ (cf. Definitions 3.9-3.11). Then for any $\boldsymbol{\alpha} \in \mathbb{N}^{m} \backslash\{0\}^{m}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in \operatorname{cmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m},\left[\boldsymbol{b}, \mathbb{E}_{\omega} \mathbb{T}_{\omega}\right]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is mean continuous from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times$

$\cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$ for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in$ $A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

As mentioned above, the biggest challenge in the multilinear setting is to obtain desired estimates in quasi-Banach range. Interestingly and unexpectedly, the mean continuity also enjoys the property of extrapolation as follows, which provides us with great convenience in practice.
Theorem 1.8. Let $\boldsymbol{\alpha} \in \mathbb{N}^{m} \backslash\{0\}^{m}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in \operatorname{bmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m}$. Assume that $T$ is an m-linear operator such that
(a) $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is mean continuous from $L^{p_{1}}\left(u_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(u_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(u^{p}\right)$ for some $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in[1, \infty]^{m}$ and for some $\vec{u}=\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $u=\prod_{j=1}^{m} u_{j}$
(b) $T$ is bounded from $L^{q_{1}}\left(v_{1}^{q_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{q_{m}}\left(v_{m}^{q_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{q}\left(v^{q}\right)$ for some $\vec{q}=\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{m}\right) \in$ $[1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{q}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{q_{j}}$ and $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$

Then $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is mean continuous from $L^{r_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{r_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{r_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{r_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{r}\left(w^{r}\right)$ for all $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

The formulation of Theorem 1.8 is inspired by Theorem 1.6. Theorem 1.8 enables us to extrapolate the mean continuity of $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ from just one unweighted space to the full range of weighted spaces, whenever an $m$-linear operator $T$ is bounded on weighted Lebesgue spaces. The proof of Theorem 1.8 contains three main ingredients: (i) interpolation of multiple weights (cf. Lemma 8.1); (ii) extrapolation of boundedness for commutators (cf. Theorem 8.21); (iii) interpolation on mixed-norm Lebesgue spaces (cf. [5, Theorem 3.5]).
1.4. Historical overview. The multi-parameter theory of singular integrals was pioneered by Fefferman and Stein [18], who dealt with bi-parameter singular integral operators of convolution type. In the language of vector-valued CalderónZygmund theory, Journé [50] formulated a $T 1$ theorem for bi-parameter singular integrals with general kernels. From a fresh viewpoint on kernels (full and partial kernel representations), Martikainen [48] introduced a class of bi-parameter singular integrals and proved a bi-parameter dyadic representation, and then obtained a bi-parameter $T 1$ theorem as a pleasant byproduct. Unexpectedly, full and partial kernel representations are actually equivalent to Journé's vector-valued formulation, see [26]. Furthermore, the bi-parameter $T 1$ theorem was extended to non-homogeneous spaces in [36] using dyadic probabilistic methods and non-homogeneous analysis. See $[8,9,10,16,17,19]$ for more classical multi-parameter results and applications.

On the other hand, there are a large number of literatures devoted to studying multilinear multi-parameter theory, which is more challenging than the multilinear one-parameter and linear multi-parameter theory of singular integrals. A typical example is bilinear bi-parameter Coifman-Meyer multipliers by Muscalu et al. [51],

which appeared naturally in the Leibniz rule for fractional derivatives. They were proved in [45] to be bilinear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operators, and the usage of modern tools in $[45,46]$ greatly enriches the multi-parameter theory of multipliers by establishing novel commutators, weighted, and square function estimates. Moreover, some interesting investigations were carried out for variants of bilinear biparameter Coifman-Meyer multipliers, such as multilinear multi-parameter Hilbert transform [14], multilinear multi-parameter pseudo-differential operators [15], multilinear multi-parameter Hörmander multipliers [12], and so on.

In term of the compactness of commutators, Uchiyama [65] first established the equivalence between $b \in \operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and $L^{p}$ compactness of commutators $[b, T]$ for any $p \in(1, \infty)$ and Calderón-Zygmund operator $T$ with smooth kernel, where $\operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ denotes the closure in $\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ of infinitely differentiable functions with compact support. A weighted analogy was proved for Riesz transforms and fractional integrals in [69]. In addition, the unweighted compactness was extended by Bényi and Torres [2] to the bilinear setting $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \times L^{p_{2}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ for $\frac{1}{p}=\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}$ with $p, p_{1}, p_{2} \in(1, \infty)$, while a complete characterization of compactness without the restriction $p \in(1, \infty)$ was shown in [7] for certain homogeneous bilinear CalderónZygmund operators. All results aforementioned were given for $b \in \operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. However, some recent works have shown that a weaker assumption is sufficient to obtain weighted compactness of commutators. In fact, introducing a new space $\operatorname{XMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ between $\mathrm{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and $\mathrm{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$, Torres and Xue [62] obtained unweighted compactness of commutators of bilinear Fourier multipliers and bilinear pseudo-differential operators. It was improved to the weighted case in [60], where an equivalent characterization of $\operatorname{XMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and the fact $\operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \subsetneq \operatorname{XMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \subsetneq \operatorname{VMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \subsetneq \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ were demonstrated in the spirit of Uchiyama's proof, although the proof needs some essential novel techniques on dyadic cubes and delicate geometrical observations. The more general fractional variants were established in [61] recently.

As a classical compactness criterion, the celebrated Kolmogorov-Riesz theorem was first discovered by Kolmogorov in $L^{p}([0,1])$ for $p \in(1, \infty)$, which is a one-parameter version of Theorem 6.1 with $w \equiv 1$ (the condition (b) holds automatically in this case). Soon after, it was expanded by Tamarkin [59] to the general situation $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, which was further extended to the case $p=1$ by Tulajkov [64]. Simultaneously, Riesz [56] independently proved a result in the form of Theorem 6.2 for $w \equiv 1$ and $p \in[1, \infty)$, which was improved to the setting $p \in(0,1)$ by Tsuji [63]. Recently, these results aforementioned were refined on weighted Lebesgue spaces $L^{p}(w)$ for general weights $w$ and exponents $p \in(0, \infty)$ in [5]. Moreover, this theorem has been generalized to various function spaces, such as Banach function spaces [21, 24], metric measure spaces [22, 27, 38], variable Lebesgue spaces [23], Musielak-Orlicz spaces [49], and weighted Lorentz spaces [4]. Beyond that, it has found many applications to Harmonic Analysis such as compactness of commutators $[2,3,4,7,61,62,65]$ and extrapolation of compactness $[3,5]$, and to PDEs such as Poiseuille flow of nematic liquid crystals [11], Beltrami equations [13], time fractional PDEs [47], motion by mean curvature [58], and so on.

1.5. Structure of the paper. This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 gives preliminaries including notation, dyadic grids, Haar functions, and some useful estimates. In Section 3, we formulate the general framework of multilinear singular integrals on product spaces. After establishing some auxiliary results in Section 4, we prove the $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation (cf. Theorem 1.4) in Section 5. Then Section 6 is devoted to showing weighted compactness of dyadic operators (cf. Theorem 1.5), while Section 7 aims to demonstrate the mean continuity of commutators (cf. Theorem 1.7). Finally, Section 8 contains the proof of extrapolation of compactness and mean continuity (cf. Theorems 1.6 and 1.8), and then shows Theorems 1.1 and 1.3. For completeness, we present all details of the proof of Uchiyama's characterization of $\operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ in Section A.

# 2. Preliminaries 

2.1. Notation. Let us introduce some useful notation in this article.

- For convenience, we use $\ell^{\infty}$ metrics on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}$ and $\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$.
- Let $\mathbb{Z}:=\{0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots\}$ be the set of all integers.
- Let $\mathbb{N}:=\{0,1,2, \ldots\}$ be the set of natural numbers.
- Let $\mathbb{N}_{+}:=\{1,2, \ldots\}$ be the set of positive integers.
- Let $\vec{f}=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right)$ denote the vector of functions $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}$.
- For any $p \in(0, \infty]$ and a weight $w$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, write $\|f\|_{L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)}:=\|f w\|_{L^{p}}$.
- Given $p \in(1, \infty)$, let $p^{\prime}=\frac{p}{p-1}$ be the Hölder conjugate exponent of $p$.
- For a measurable set $A \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $0<|A|<\infty$, write $\langle f\rangle_{A}=\oint_{A} f d x:=$ $\frac{1}{|A|} \int_{A} f d x$
- A cube $I$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ means $I:=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left[a_{i}, a_{i}+\ell\right)$, where $a_{i} \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\ell>0$.
- Given a cube $I \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$, let $c_{I}$ and $\ell(I)$ be its center and sidelength respectively. For any $\lambda>0$, let $\lambda I$ be the cube with center $c_{I}$ and sidelength $\lambda \ell(I)$.
- Write $\mathbb{I}^{i}:=\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right)^{n_{i}} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ and $\lambda \mathbb{I}^{i}:=\left[-\frac{\lambda}{2}, \frac{\lambda}{2}\right)^{n_{i}}$ for any $\lambda>0$.
- Let $\mathcal{Q}^{i}$ denote the family of all cubes in $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$. Then set $\mathcal{R}:=\mathcal{Q}^{1} \times \mathcal{Q}^{2}$.
- Let $\mathcal{D}^{i}$ denote a generic dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ (cf. Section 2.2).
- For any $I \in \mathcal{D}^{i}$, set $\operatorname{ch}(I):=\left\{I^{\prime} \in \mathcal{D}^{i}: I^{\prime} \subset I, \ell\left(I^{\prime}\right)=\ell(I) / 2\right\}$.
- Given $k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $I \in \mathcal{D}^{i}$, write $\mathcal{D}_{k}^{i}(I):=\left\{I^{\prime} \in \mathcal{D}^{i}: I^{\prime} \subset I, \ell\left(I^{\prime}\right)=2^{-k} \ell(I)\right\}$, and let $I^{(k)}$ denote the unique dyadic cube $J \in \mathcal{D}^{i}$ such that $I \subset J$ and $\ell(J)=2^{k} \ell(I)$.
- The distance between sets $E$ and $F$ is given by $\mathrm{d}(E, F):=\inf \{|x-y|: x \in$ $E, y \in F\}$.
- The relative distance between cubes $I$ and $J$ is defined by $\operatorname{rd}(I, J):=\frac{\mathrm{d}(I, J)}{\max \{\ell(I), \ell(J)\}}$.
- For every $N \in \mathbb{N}$, set $\mathcal{D}^{i}(N):=\left\{I \in \mathcal{D}^{i}: 2^{-N} \leq \ell(I) \leq 2^{N}, \operatorname{rd}\left(I, 2^{N} \mathbb{I}^{i}\right) \leq N\right\}$.
- We shall use $A \lesssim B$ and $A \simeq B$ to mean, respectively, that $A \leq C B$ and $0<c \leq A / B \leq C$, where the constants $c$ and $C$ are harmless positive constants, not necessarily the same at each occurrence, which depend only on dimension and the constants appearing in the hypotheses of theorems.

2.2. Dyadic grids. For each $i=1,2$, let $\mathcal{D}_{0}^{n_{i}}$ be the standard dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ :

$$
\mathcal{D}_{0}^{n_{i}}:=\left\{2^{-k}\left([0,1)^{n_{i}}+m\right): k \in \mathbb{Z}, m \in \mathbb{Z}^{n_{i}}\right\}
$$

Let $\Omega_{i}:=\left(\{0,1\}^{n_{i}}\right)^{\mathbb{Z}}$ and let $\mathbb{P}_{\omega_{i}}$ be the natural probability measure on $\Omega_{i}$ : each component $\omega_{i}^{j}$ has an equal probability $2^{-n_{i}}$ of taking any of the $2^{n_{i}}$ values in $\{0,1\}^{n_{i}}$, and all components are independent of each other. Let $\mathbb{E}_{\omega_{i}}$ denote the expectation over the random variables $\omega_{i}^{j}, j \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Given $\omega_{i}=\left(\omega_{i}^{j}\right)_{j \in \mathbb{Z}} \in \Omega_{i}$, the random dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ is defined by

$$
\mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}:=\left\{I+\omega_{i}:=I+\sum_{j: 2^{-j}<\ell(Q)} 2^{-j} \omega_{i}^{j}: I \in \mathcal{D}_{0}^{n_{i}}\right\}
$$

A dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}^{n_{i}}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ means $\mathcal{D}^{n_{i}}=\mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}$ for some $\omega_{i} \in \Omega_{i}$.
A cube $I \in \mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}$ is called bad if there exists a cube $J \in \mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}$ such that

$$
\ell(J) \geq 2^{\vartheta} \ell(I) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathrm{d}(I, \partial J) \leq 2 \ell(I)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell(J)^{1-\gamma_{i}}
$$

where $\vartheta \in \mathbb{N}_{+}, \gamma_{i}=\frac{\delta_{i}}{2\left(2 n_{i}+\delta_{i}\right)}$, and $\delta_{i} \in(0,1]$ appears in the kernel estimates (cf. Section 3). Otherwise a cube is called good. Let $\mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}, \text { good }}^{n_{i}}$ denote the family of good cubes in $\mathcal{D}_{\omega_{i}}^{n_{i}}$. Note that $\pi_{\text {good }}^{n_{i}}:=\mathbb{P}_{\omega_{i}}\left(I+\omega_{i}\right.$ is good $)=\mathbb{E}_{\omega_{i}} \mathbf{1}_{\text {good }}\left(I+\omega_{i}\right)$ is independent of the choice of $I \in \mathcal{D}_{0}^{n_{i}}$. The appearing parameter $\vartheta \in \mathbb{N}_{+}$is a large enough fixed integer so that $\pi_{\text {good }}^{n_{1}}>0$ and $\pi_{\text {good }}^{n_{2}}>0$. Moreover, given $I \in \mathcal{D}_{0}^{n_{i}}$, the set $I+\omega_{i}$ depends on $\omega_{i}^{j}$ with $2^{-j}<\ell(I)$, while the goodness of $I+\omega_{i}$ depends on $\omega_{i}^{j}$ with $2^{-j} \geq \ell(I)$.

The following lemma (see [44]) gives the existence of the common dyadic ancestor in two different situations.

Lemma 2.1. Let $I, J \in \mathcal{D}^{n_{i}}$ and $K \in \mathcal{D}_{\text {good }}^{n_{i}}$ be such that $\ell(K) \leq \ell(I)=2 \ell(J)$.
(a) If $\max \{\mathrm{d}(K, I), \mathrm{d}(K, J)\}>2 \ell(K)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell(J)^{1-\gamma_{i}}$, then there exists a cube $Q \in \mathcal{D}^{n_{i}}$ such that

$$
I \cup J \cup K \subset Q \quad \text { and } \quad \max \{\mathrm{d}(K, I), \mathrm{d}(K, J)\} \gtrsim \ell(K)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell(Q)^{1-\gamma_{i}}
$$

(b) If $\max \{\mathrm{d}(K, I), \mathrm{d}(K, J)\} \leq 2 \ell(K)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell(J)^{1-\gamma_{i}}$ and either $K \cap I=\emptyset$ or $K=I$ or $K \cap J=\varnothing$, then there exists a cube $Q \in \mathcal{D}^{n_{i}}$ such that

$$
I \cup J \cup K \subset Q \quad \text { and } \quad \ell(Q) \leq 2^{\vartheta} \ell(K)
$$

2.3. Haar functions. Let $\mathcal{D}$ be a dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Given a cube $I=I_{1} \times \cdots \times I_{n} \in$ $\mathcal{D}$, define the Haar function $h_{I}^{\eta}, \eta=\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{n}\right) \in\{0,1\}^{n}$, by

$$
h_{I}^{\eta}:=h_{I_{1}}^{\eta_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes h_{I_{n}}^{\eta_{n}}
$$

where $h_{I_{i}}^{0}=\left|I_{i}\right|^{-\frac{1}{2}} \mathbf{1}_{I_{i}}$ and $h_{I_{i}}^{1}=\left|I_{i}\right|^{-\frac{1}{2}}\left(\mathbf{1}_{I_{i}^{-}}-\mathbf{1}_{I_{i}^{+}}\right)$for every $i=1, \ldots, n$. Here $I_{i}^{-}$ and $I_{i}^{+}$are the left and right halves of the interval $I_{i}$ respectively. If $\eta \neq 0$, the Haar function is cancellative : $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} h_{I}^{\eta} d x=0$; in this case we usually suppress the presence of $\eta$ and simply write $h_{I}=h_{I}^{\eta}$.

Given $k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $I \in \mathcal{D}$, let $\mathcal{D}_{k}(I):=\left\{I^{\prime} \in \mathcal{D}: I^{\prime} \subset I, \ell\left(I^{\prime}\right)=2^{-k} \ell(I)\right\}$. Define

$$
E_{I} f:=\langle f\rangle_{I} \mathbf{1}_{I}, \quad \Delta_{I} f:=\sum_{I^{\prime} \in \operatorname{ch}(I)}\left[\langle f\rangle_{I^{\prime}}-\langle f\rangle_{I}\right] \mathbf{1}_{I^{\prime}}, \quad \text { and } \quad \Delta_{I}^{k} f:=\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}_{k}(I)} \Delta_{I} f
$$

Then for all $p \in(1, \infty)$ and $f \in L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$,

$$
f=\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}} \Delta_{I} f=\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}}\left\langle f, h_{I}\right\rangle h_{I}
$$

where the convergence takes place unconditionally in $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.
The dyadic square function $S_{\mathcal{D}}$ is defined by

$$
S_{\mathcal{D}} f:=\left(\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}}\left|\left\langle f, h_{I}\right\rangle\right|^{2} \frac{\mathbf{1}_{I}}{|I|}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

It was shown in [68, Theorem 2.1] that

$$
\left\|S_{\mathcal{D}} f\right\|_{L^{r}} \simeq\|f\|_{L^{r}}, \quad \text { for all } r \in(1, \infty)
$$

For each $k \in \mathbb{Z}$, setting

$$
E_{2^{k}} f:=\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}: \ell(Q)=2^{k}} E_{Q} f \quad \text { and } \quad D_{2^{k}} f:=E_{2^{k-1}} f-E_{2^{k}} f
$$

one can verify

$$
E_{2^{k}} f=\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}: \ell(Q)>2^{k}} \Delta_{Q} f, \quad D_{2^{k}} f=\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}: \ell(Q)=2^{k}} \Delta_{Q} f
$$

and

$$
\left\|\left(\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}}\left|D_{2^{k}} f\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{r}} \simeq\|f\|_{L^{r}}, \quad \text { for all } r \in(1, \infty)
$$

Given $N \in \mathbb{N}$, we define the projection operator and its orthogonal operator by

$$
P_{\mathcal{D}(N)} f:=\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}(N)}\left\langle f, h_{I}\right\rangle h_{I} \quad \text { and } \quad P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp} f:=f-P_{\mathcal{D}(N)} f
$$

with convergence interpreted pointwise almost everywhere. Then there holds

$$
\sup _{N \in \mathbb{N}}\left\|P_{N}^{\perp} f\right\|_{L^{r}} \lesssim\|f\|_{L^{r}}, \quad \text { for all } r \in(1, \infty)
$$

2.4. Muckenhoupt weights. A measurable function $w$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ is called a weight if $0<w(x)<\infty$ a.e. $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$. Given $p \in(1, \infty)$, we define the bi-parameter class $A_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ as the collection of all weights $w$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ satisfying

$$
[w]_{A_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}:=\sup _{R \in \mathcal{R}}\langle w\rangle_{R}\left\langle w^{1-p^{\prime}}\right\rangle_{R}^{p-1}<\infty
$$

In the endpoint case $p=1$, we say that $w \in A_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ if

$$
[w]_{A_{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}:=\sup _{R \in \mathcal{R}}\langle w\rangle_{R}\left(\operatorname{ess}_{\sup _{R}} w^{-1}\right)<\infty
$$

Then, we define $A_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right):=\bigcup_{p \geq 1} A_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$.
Let us record square function estimates (cf. [30, p. 1705]): for any $p \in(1, \infty)$ and $w \in A_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|f\|_{L^{p}(w)} & \simeq\left\|\left[\sum_{\substack{I^{1} \in \mathcal{D}^{1} \\
I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}}\left|\Delta_{I^{1}} \Delta_{I^{2}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)}=\left\|\left[\sum_{\substack{I^{1} \in \mathcal{D}^{1} \\
I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}}\left|\Delta_{I^{1}}^{k_{1}} \Delta_{I^{2}}^{k_{2}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)} \\
& \simeq\left\|\left[\sum_{I^{1} \in \mathcal{D}^{1}}\left|\Delta_{I^{1}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)}=\left\|\left[\sum_{I^{1} \in \mathcal{D}^{1}}\left|\Delta_{I^{1}}^{k_{1}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)} \\
& \simeq\left\|\left[\sum_{I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}\left|\Delta_{I^{2}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)}=\left\|\left[\sum_{I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}\left|\Delta_{I^{2}}^{k_{2}} f\right|^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{p}(w)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $k_{1}, k_{2} \in \mathbb{N}$, where the implicit constants are independent of $k_{1}, k_{2}, \mathcal{D}^{1}, \mathcal{D}^{2}$.
Next, let us recall multiple weights on product spaces introduced in [25].
Definition 2.12. Given $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right)$ with $1 \leq p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \leq \infty$ and $\vec{w}=$ $\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right)$ with $0<w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}<\infty$ a.e. on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$, we say that $\vec{w} \in$ $A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ if

$$
[\vec{w}]_{A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}:=\sup _{R \in \mathcal{R}}\left\langle w^{p}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{p}} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\langle w_{j}^{-p_{j}^{\prime}}\right\rangle_{R}^{\frac{1}{p_{j}^{\prime}}}<\infty
$$

where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. If $p_{j}=1,\left\langle w_{j}^{-p_{j}^{\prime}}\right\rangle_{R}^{\frac{1}{p_{j}^{\prime}}}$ is understood as $\left(\operatorname{ess} \inf _{R} w_{j}\right)^{-1}$; and if $p=\infty,\left\langle w^{p}\right\rangle^{\frac{1}{p}}$ is understood as $\operatorname{ess} \sup _{R} w$.

Let us define the multilinear strong maximal operator

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{R}}\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right)(x):=\sup _{x \in R \in \mathcal{R}} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left(\left|f_{j}\right|\right\rangle_{R}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}
$$

In the case $m=1$, simply write $M_{\mathcal{R}}=\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{R}}$.
Analogously to [41], we have the following characterizations of the class $A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times\right.$ $\left.\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, see [46, Lemma 3.6] and [25, Corollary 2.4]. Although the latter does not contain the case $p_{i}=\infty$ for some/all $i \in\{1, \ldots, m\}$, it can be shown by Proposition 4.1 and Remark 8.1 in [46].

Theorem 2.13. Let $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right)$ with $1 \leq p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \leq \infty$. Then the following hold:
(1) $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ if and only if $w^{p} \in A_{m p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $w_{j}^{-p_{j}^{\prime}} \in A_{m p_{j}^{\prime}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times\right.$ $\left.\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right), j=1, \ldots, m$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. If $p_{j}=1, w_{j}^{-p_{j}^{\prime}} \in$ $A_{m p_{j}^{\prime}}$ is understood as $w_{j}^{1 / m} \in A_{1}$; and if $p=\infty, w^{p} \in A_{m p}$ is understood as $w^{-1 / m} \in A_{1}$.

(2) Let $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}>1$. Then $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ if and only if $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{R}}$ is bounded from $L^{p_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{p_{m}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.

# 2.5. BMO and CMO spaces. 

Definition 2.14. A locally integrable function $b: \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ belongs to $\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ if

$$
\|b\|_{\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)}:=\sup _{Q \in \mathcal{Q}} \oint_{Q}|b(x)-\langle b\rangle_{Q}| d x<\infty
$$

where $\mathcal{Q}$ is the collection of all cubes on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. A dyadic analogue $\operatorname{BMO}(\mathcal{D})$ is defined on the dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}$ instead of $\mathcal{Q}$. Let $\operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ denote the closure of $\mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ in $\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. Additionally, the space $\mathrm{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ is endowed with the norm of $\mathrm{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.

It follows from $[39,65]$ and the John-Neirenberg inequality that for any $p \in[1, \infty)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
b \in \operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) & \Longleftrightarrow b \in \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \text { and } \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{Q \notin \mathcal{Q}(N)}\left[\oint_{Q}\left|b-\langle b\rangle_{Q}\right|^{p}\right]^{\frac{1}{p}}=0 \\
& \Longleftrightarrow b \in \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) \text { and } \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\mathcal{D}}\left\|P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp} b\right\|_{\operatorname{BMO}(\mathcal{D})}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first equivalence is shown in Theorem A. 1 and the second equivalence is given in [4, Theorem A.1]. Moreover, for any sequence $\left\{a_{I}\right\}_{I \in \mathcal{D}}$ and $\left\{b_{I}\right\}_{I \in \mathcal{D}}$,

$$
\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}}\left|a_{I}\right|\left|b_{I}\right| \lesssim \sup _{Q \in \mathcal{D}}\left(\frac{1}{|Q|} \sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}: I \subset Q}\left|a_{I}\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\left\|\left(\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}}\left|b_{I}\right|^{2} \frac{\mathbf{1}_{I}}{|I|}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{1}}
$$

Next, let us turn to BMO and CMO spaces in the product setting $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$. Let $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}$, where $\mathcal{D}^{i}$ is a dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}, i=1,2$. We say that a locally integrable function $b: \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ belongs to the dyadic little BMO space $\operatorname{bmo}(\mathcal{D})$ if

$$
\|b\|_{\operatorname{bmo}(\mathcal{D})}:=\sup _{I=I^{1} \times I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}} \oint_{I}|b(x)-\langle b\rangle_{I}| d x<\infty
$$

The little BMO space bmo $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ is defined as the set of all functions $b$ satisfying

$$
\|b\|_{\operatorname{bmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}:=\sup _{\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}}\|b\|_{\operatorname{bmo}(\mathcal{D})}<\infty
$$

Then little CMO space $\operatorname{cmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ is defined as the closure of $\mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ in bmo $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ with norm of bmo $\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$.

We say that a locally integrable function $b: \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ belongs to the dyadic product $\operatorname{BMO}$ space $\operatorname{BMO}(\mathcal{D})$ if

$$
\|b\|_{\operatorname{BMO}(\mathcal{D})}:=\sup _{U}\left(\frac{1}{|U|} \sum_{\substack{I^{1} \times I^{2} \in \mathcal{D} \\ I^{1} \times I^{2} \subset U}}\left|\left\langle b, h_{I^{1}} \otimes h_{I^{2}}\right\rangle\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}<\infty
$$

where the supremum is taken over all open sets $U \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ with $0<|U|<\infty$. Then the product BMO space $\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ is defined as the collection of all

locally integrable functions $b$ satisfying

$$
\|b\|_{\mathrm{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}:=\sup _{\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}}\|b\|_{\mathrm{BMO}(\mathcal{D})}<\infty
$$

We say that $b$ belongs to the dyadic product $\mathrm{CMO}$ space $\mathrm{CMO}(\mathcal{D})$ if $b \in \mathrm{BMO}(\mathcal{D})$ and satisfies

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty}\left\|P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp} b\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}(\mathcal{D})}=0
$$

where $\mathcal{D}(N):=\mathcal{D}^{1}(N) \times \mathcal{D}^{2}(N), P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp} b:=b-P_{\mathcal{D}(N)} b$, and

$$
P_{\mathcal{D}(N)} b:=\sum_{J^{1} \times J^{2} \in \mathcal{D}(N)}\left\langle b, h_{J^{1}} \otimes h_{J^{2}}\right\rangle h_{J^{1}} \otimes h_{J^{2}}
$$

The product $\mathrm{CMO}$ space $\mathrm{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ is defined as the set of all functions $b \in$ $\operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ satisfying

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\mathcal{D}}\left\|P_{\mathcal{D}(N)}^{\perp} b\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}(\mathcal{D})}=0
$$

For later use, we present a bi-parameter Carleson embedding theorem, which is a particular result of [28].
Lemma 2.16. Let $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}$, where $\mathcal{D}^{i}$ is a dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}, i=1,2$. Then the following are equivalent:
(i) A family of non-negative numbers $\left\{\lambda_{R}\right\}_{R \in \mathcal{D}}$ is Carleson:

$$
\sum_{R \in \mathcal{D}: R \subset U} \lambda_{R} \leq C_{1}|U|, \quad \text { for all open sets } U \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}
$$

(ii) For every family $\left\{a_{R}\right\}_{R \in \mathcal{D}}$ of nonnegative numbers, there holds

$$
\sum_{R \in \mathcal{D}} \lambda_{R} a_{R} \leq C_{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}} \sup _{x \in R \in \mathcal{D}} a_{R} d x
$$

Let us end up this section with the relationship of compactness on two separated spaces and on product spaces.

Lemma 2.17. Let $p, p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \in(0, \infty)$. For each $i=1,2$, let $T_{i}: L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \times$ $\cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)$ boundedly with operator norm being non-zero. If $T_{1} \otimes T_{2}$ is compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, then $T_{i}$ is compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)$ for each $i=1,2$.

Proof. Assume that $T_{1}$ is not compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)$. Then there exists a bounded sequence $\left\{\left(f_{k}^{1}, \ldots, f_{k}^{m}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty} \subset L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)$ so that for every subsequence $\left\{\left(f_{k_{j}}^{1}, \ldots, f_{k_{j}}^{m}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{\infty}$ of $\left\{\left(f_{k}^{1}, \ldots, f_{k}^{m}\right)\right\}_{k=1}^{\infty},\left\{T_{1}\left(f_{k_{j}}^{1}, \ldots, f_{k_{j}}^{m}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{\infty}$ is not Cauchy in $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)$. By the fact that $T_{2}$ is non-zero, one can find some $g^{i} \in L^{p_{i}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right), i=1, \ldots, m$, satisfying $\left\|T_{2}\left(g^{1}, \ldots, g^{m}\right)\right\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}=: A_{0} \in(0, \infty)$.

Pick $\phi_{k}^{i}:=f_{k}^{i} \otimes g^{i}$ for each $k \in \mathbb{N}_{+}$and $i=1, \ldots, m$. By definition, we have

$$
\left\|T_{1} \otimes T_{2}\left(\phi_{k_{i}}^{1}, \ldots, \phi_{k_{i}}^{m}\right)-T_{1} \otimes T_{2}\left(\phi_{k_{j}}^{1}, \ldots, \phi_{k_{j}}^{m}\right)\right\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)}
$$

$$
=A_{0}\left\|T_{1}\left(\phi_{k_{i}}^{1}, \ldots, \phi_{k_{i}}^{m}\right)-T_{1}\left(\phi_{k_{j}}^{1}, \ldots, \phi_{k_{j}}^{m}\right)\right\|_{L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right)}
$$

for all $i, j \in \mathbb{N}_{+}$, which implies that $\left\{T_{1} \otimes T_{2}\left(\phi_{k_{j}}^{1}, \ldots, \phi_{k_{j}}^{m}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{\infty}$ is not Cauchy in $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Hence, $T_{1} \otimes T_{2}$ is not compact from $L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ to $L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$.

# 3. MULTILINEAR SINGULAR INTEGRALS ON PRODUCT SPACES 

Let us define multilinear singular integrals on product spaces. Let $T$ be an $m$-linear operator on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$. Let $f_{j}=f_{j}^{1} \otimes f_{j}^{2}, j=1, \ldots, m+1$. Denote $T_{1,2}^{0 *, 0 *}:=T$, and for each $j \in\{1, \ldots, m\}$, we define the full adjoint $T_{1,2}^{j *, j *}:=T^{j *}$ by

$$
\left\langle T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=\left\langle T^{j *}\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{j-1}, f_{m+1}, f_{j+1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{j}\right\rangle
$$

and define the partial adjoints $T_{1,2}^{j *, 0 *}:=T_{1}^{j *}$ and $T_{1,2}^{0 *, j *}:=T_{2}^{j *}$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\langle T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=\left\langle T_{1}^{j *}\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{j-1}, f_{m+1}^{1} \otimes f_{j}^{2}, f_{j+1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{j}^{1} \otimes f_{m+1}^{2}\right\rangle \\
& \left\langle T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=\left\langle T_{2}^{j *}\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{j-1}, f_{j}^{1} \otimes f_{m+1}^{2}, f_{j+1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}^{1} \otimes f_{j}^{2}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Then for any $j_{1}, j_{2} \in\{1, \ldots, m\}$, we define $T_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}$ by taking partial adjoints of $T_{1}^{j_{1} *}$ with respect to the second parameter, i.e., $T_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}=\left(T_{1}^{j_{1} *}\right)_{2}^{j_{2} *}$.

Definition 3.1. Let $\mathscr{F}$ consist of all triples $\left(F_{1}, F_{2}, F_{3}\right)$ of bounded functions $F_{1}, F_{2}, F_{3}$ : $[0, \infty) \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ satisfying

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} F_{1}(t)=\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} F_{2}(t)=\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} F_{3}(t)=0
$$

For $i=1,2$, let $\mathscr{F}^{i}$ be the family of all bounded functions $F^{i}: \mathcal{Q}^{i} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ satisfying

$$
\lim _{\ell\left(I^{i}\right) \rightarrow 0} F^{i}\left(I^{i}\right)=\lim _{\ell\left(I^{i}\right) \rightarrow \infty} F^{i}\left(I^{i}\right)=\lim _{\left|c_{I^{i}}\right| \rightarrow \infty} F^{i}\left(I^{i}\right)=0
$$

where $\mathcal{Q}^{i}$ is the collection of all cubes in $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}, i=1,2$.
Let $\mathbb{F}^{i}$ consist of all finite linear combinations of indicators of cubes in $\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}, i=1,2$. Set $\mathbb{F}=\mathbb{F}^{1} \times \mathbb{F}^{2}$. Let $\mathbb{L}$ denote the set of locally integrable functions on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$. Let $\delta_{1}, \delta_{2} \in(0,1]$. For convenience, we use $\ell^{\infty}$ metrics on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}$ and $\mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ throughout this paper.

First, we define the kernel estimates.
Definition 3.2. An $m$-linear operator $T: \mathbb{F} \times \cdots \times \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{L}$ admits a compact full kernel representation if the following hold. If $f_{j}=f_{j}^{1} \otimes f_{j}^{2} \in \mathbb{F}, j=1, \ldots, m+1$, and $\operatorname{supp}\left(f_{1}^{i}\right) \cap \cdots \cap \operatorname{supp}\left(f_{m+1}^{i}\right)=\varnothing, i=1,2$, then

$$
\left\langle T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=\int_{\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{(m+1)}} K\left(x_{m+1}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right) \prod_{j=1}^{m+1} f_{j}\left(x_{j}\right) d x
$$

where

$$
K: \mathbb{R}^{\left(n_{1}+n_{2}\right)(m+1)} \backslash\left\{x_{1}^{1}=\cdots=x_{m+1}^{1} \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \text { or } x_{1}^{2}=\cdots=x_{m+1}^{2} \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}
$$

is the kernel satisfying

(1) the size condition

$$
\left|K\left(x_{m+1}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)\right| \leq \prod_{i=1}^{2} \frac{F^{i}\left(x_{m+1}^{i}, x_{1}^{i}, \ldots, x_{m}^{i}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|\right)^{m n_{i}}}
$$

(2) the Hölder condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K\left(x_{m+1}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)-K\left(\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, \widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{2}\right), x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)\right. \\
& \quad-K\left(\left(\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}, x_{m+1}^{2}\right), x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)+K\left(\left(\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}, \widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{2}\right), x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right) \mid \\
& \leq \prod_{i=1}^{2}\left(\frac{\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{i}\right|}{\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|}\right)^{\delta_{i}} \frac{F^{i}\left(x_{m+1}^{i}, x_{1}^{i}, \ldots, x_{m}^{i}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|\right)^{m n_{i}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever $\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{i}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2} \max \left\{\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|: 1 \leq j \leq m\right\}$ for all $i=1,2$.
(3) the mixed size-Hölder condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K\left(x_{m+1}, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)-K\left(\left(\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}, x_{m+1}^{2}\right), x_{1}, \ldots, x_{m}\right)\right| \\
& \quad \leq\left(\frac{\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}\right|}{\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|}\right)^{\delta_{1}} \prod_{i=1}^{2} \frac{F^{i}\left(x_{m+1}^{i}, x_{1}^{i}, \ldots, x_{m}^{i}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|\right)^{m n_{i}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever $\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2} \max \left\{\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|: 1 \leq j \leq m\right\}$.
(4) the function $F^{i}$ in (1)-(3) is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F^{i}\left(x_{m+1}^{i}, x_{1}^{i}, \ldots, x_{m}^{i}\right) \\
& :=F_{1}^{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|\right) F_{2}^{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}-x_{j}^{i}\right|\right) F_{3}^{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{i}+x_{j}^{i}\right|\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\left(F_{1}^{i}, F_{2}^{i}, F_{3}^{i}\right) \in \mathscr{F}, i=1,2$.
(5) The kernels $K_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}$ of $T_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}, j_{1}, j_{2} \in\{0,1,2\}$, satisfy properties (1)-(4) as well.

Definition 3.3. An $m$-linear operator $T: \mathbb{F} \times \cdots \times \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{L}$ admits a compact partial kernel representation on the first parameter if the following hold. If $f_{j}=f_{j}^{1} \otimes f_{j}^{2}$, $j=1, \ldots, m+1$, and $\operatorname{supp}\left(f_{1}^{1}\right) \cap \cdots \cap \operatorname{supp}\left(f_{m+1}^{1}\right)=\varnothing$, then

$$
\left\langle T\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}(m+1)}} K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right) \prod_{j=1}^{m+1} f_{j}^{1}\left(x_{j}^{1}\right) d x^{1}
$$

where

$$
K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}: \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}(m+1)} \backslash\left\{x_{1}^{1}=\cdots=x_{m+1}^{1} \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}\right\} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}
$$

is the the kernel satisfying
(1) the size condition

$$
\left|K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)\right| \leq C\left(f_{1}^{2}, \ldots, f_{m+1}^{2}\right) \frac{F^{1}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|\right)^{m n_{1}}}
$$

(2) the Hölder condition

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)-\left|K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)\right|\right. \\
& \leq C\left(f_{1}^{2}, \ldots, f_{m+1}^{2}\right)\left(\frac{\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}\right|}{\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|}\right)^{\delta_{1}} \frac{F^{1}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|\right)^{m n_{1}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever $\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{m+1}^{1}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2} \max \left\{\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|: 1 \leq j \leq m\right\}$, and for each $j \in\{1, \ldots, m\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{j}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)-\left|K_{\left(f_{j}^{2}\right)}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, \widetilde{x}_{j}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)\right|\right. \\
& \leq C\left(f_{1}^{2}, \ldots, f_{m+1}^{2}\right)\left(\frac{\left|x_{j}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{j}^{1}\right|}{\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|}\right)^{\delta_{1}} \frac{F^{1}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right)}{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|\right)^{m n_{1}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

whenever $\left|x_{j}^{1}-\widetilde{x}_{j}^{1}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2} \max \left\{\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|: 1 \leq j \leq m\right\}$.
(3) the function $F^{1}$ in (1)-(2) is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F^{1}\left(x_{m+1}^{1}, x_{1}^{1}, \ldots, x_{m}^{1}\right) \\
& :=F_{1}^{1}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|\right) F_{2}^{1}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}-x_{j}^{1}\right|\right) F_{3}^{1}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left|x_{m+1}^{1}+x_{j}^{1}\right|\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\left(F_{1}^{1}, F_{2}^{1}, F_{3}^{1}\right) \in \mathscr{F}$.
(4) the minimal bound $C\left(f_{1}^{2}, \ldots, f_{m+1}^{2}\right)$ above verifies

$$
\begin{aligned}
C\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right)+C\left(a_{I^{2}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right) & \leq F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\left|I^{2}\right| \\
C\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, a_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right)+\cdots+C\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, a_{I^{2}}\right) & \leq F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\left|I^{2}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

for all cubes $I^{2} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ and all functions $a_{I^{2}}$ satisfying $\operatorname{supp}\left(a_{I^{2}}\right) \subset I^{2},\left|a_{I^{2}}\right| \leq 1$, and $\int a_{I^{2}}=0$, where $F^{2} \in \mathscr{F}^{2}$.

Analogously, one can define a compact partial kernel representation on the second parameter when $\operatorname{supp}\left(f_{1}^{2}\right) \cap \cdots \cap \operatorname{supp}\left(f_{m+1}^{2}\right)=\varnothing$.

Definition 3.4. Let $T$ be an $m$-linear operator.

- We say that $T$ admits the compact partial kernel representation if it admits a compact partial kernel representation on both the first and second parameters.
- We say that $T$ admits the full kernel representation if both $F^{1}$ and $F^{2}$ in the compact full kernel representation is replaced by a uniform constant $C \geq 1$.
- We say that $T$ admits the partial kernel representation if both $F^{1}$ and $F^{2}$ in compact partial kernel representations are replaced by a uniform constant $C \geq 1$.
- If $T$ admits the full and partial kernel representations, we call $T$ an $m$-linear bi-parameter singular integral operator.

Next, let us give compactness assumptions.

Definition 3.5. We say that $T$ satisfies the weak compactness property if

$$
\left|\left\langle T\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right), \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right\rangle\right| \leq F^{1}\left(I^{1}\right)\left|I^{1}\right| F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\left|I^{2}\right|
$$

for all cubes $I^{1} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}$ and $I^{2} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$, where $F^{1} \in \mathscr{F}^{1}$ and $F^{2} \in \mathscr{F}^{2}$. We say that $T$ satisfies the weak boundedness property if both $F^{1}$ and $F^{2}$ above are replaced by a uniform constant $C \geq 1$.

Moreover, let us introduce cancellation assumptions.
Definition 3.6. We say that $T$ satisfies the diagonal CMO condition if for each $i=1,2$, for any cube $I^{i} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$, and for any function $a_{I^{i}}$ such that $\operatorname{supp}\left(a_{I^{i}}\right) \subset I^{i}$, $\left|a_{I^{i}}\right| \leq 1$, and $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}} a_{I^{i}} d x_{i}=0$, there holds

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\left\langle T\left(a_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right), \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right\rangle\right| \leq F^{1}\left(I^{1}\right)\left|I^{1}\right| F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\left|I^{2}\right|, \\
& \ldots \ldots \\
& \left|\left\langle T\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right), a_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right\rangle\right| \leq F^{1}\left(I^{1}\right)\left|I^{1}\right| F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\left|I^{2}\right|, \\
& \quad \ldots \ldots \\
& \left|\left\langle T\left(\mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}, \ldots, \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes \mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}\right), \mathbf{1}_{I^{1}} \otimes a_{I^{2}}\right\rangle\left|\leq F^{1}\left(I^{1}\right)\right| I^{1}\left|F^{2}\left(I^{2}\right)\right| I^{2}\right|,
\end{aligned}
$$

where $F^{1} \in \mathscr{F}^{1}$ and $F^{2} \in \mathscr{F}^{2}$. We say that $T$ satisfies the diagonal BMO condition if both $F^{1}$ and $F^{2}$ above are replaced by a uniform constant $C \geq 1$.

Definition 3.7. An $m$-linear operator $T$ satisfies the product BMO condition if

$$
T_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}(1, \ldots, 1) \in \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \quad \text { for all } j_{1}, j_{2} \in\{0,1, \ldots, m\}
$$

We say that $T$ satisfies the product CMO condition if

$$
T_{1,2}^{j_{1} *, j_{2} *}(1, \ldots, 1) \in \operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \quad \text { for all } j_{1}, j_{2} \in\{0,1, \ldots, m\}
$$

Definition 3.8. An operator $T$ is called an m-linear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operator if it admits full and partial kernel representations, and satisfies the weak boundedness property and the diagonal and product BMO conditions.

Beyond that, we would like to define $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic operators, whose simple dyadic structure plays a significant role in our analysis.
Definition 3.9. Given a dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}$ and $k=\left(k_{1}, \ldots, k_{m+1}\right)$ with $k_{j}=\left(k_{j}^{1}, k_{j}^{2}\right) \in \mathbb{N}^{2}$, a compact m-linear bi-parameter shift $\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}}^{k}$ of complexity $k$ is defined by

$$
\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}}^{k}(\vec{f}):=\sum_{Q=Q^{1} \times Q^{2} \in \mathcal{D}} \sum_{\substack{I_{j} \in \mathcal{D}_{k_{j}}(Q) \\ j=1, \ldots, m+1}} a_{\left(I_{j}\right), Q} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\langle f_{j}, \widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{1}} \otimes \widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{2}}\right\rangle \widetilde{h}_{I_{m+1}^{1}} \otimes \widetilde{h}_{I_{m+1}^{2}}
$$

where $I_{j}=I_{j}^{1} \times I_{j}^{2}, \mathcal{D}_{k_{j}}(Q):=\mathcal{D}_{k_{j}^{1}}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right) \times \mathcal{D}_{k_{j}^{2}}^{2}\left(Q^{2}\right), \mathcal{D}_{k_{j}^{1}}^{i}\left(Q^{i}\right):=\left\{I^{i} \in \mathcal{D}^{i}: I^{i} \subset\right.$ $\left.Q^{i}, \ell\left(I^{i}\right)=2^{-k_{j}^{i}} \ell\left(Q^{i}\right)\right\}$, and $\widetilde{h}_{I_{j}}:=\widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{1}} \otimes \widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{2}}$. Here we assume that for each $i=1,2$,

there exist two different indices $j_{0}^{i}, j_{1}^{i} \in\{1, \ldots, m+1\}$ so that $\widetilde{h}_{I_{0}^{i}}=h_{I_{0}^{i}}, \widetilde{h}_{I_{1}^{i}}=h_{I_{1}^{i}}$, and $\widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{i}} \in\left\{h_{I_{j}^{i}}^{0}, h_{I_{j}^{i}}\right\}$ for every $j \neq j_{0}^{i}, j_{1}^{i}$. Moreover, the coefficients $a_{\left(I_{j}\right), Q}$ satisfy

$$
\left|a_{\left(I_{j}\right), Q}\right| \leq \mathcal{F}(Q) \frac{\prod_{j=1}^{m+1}\left|I_{j}\right|^{\frac{1}{2}}}{|Q|^{m}}
$$

with

$$
\mathcal{F}(Q) \leq 1 \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \mathcal{F}_{N}:=\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\mathcal{D}} \sup _{Q \notin \mathcal{D}(N)} \mathcal{F}(Q)=0
$$

where $\mathcal{D}(N):=\mathcal{D}^{1}(N) \times \mathcal{D}^{2}(N)$. Similarly, we define an $m$-linear bi-parameter shift $\mathbb{S}_{\mathcal{D}}^{k}$ of complexity $k$ if $\mathcal{F}(Q) \equiv 1$.

Definition 3.10. Given a dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}$ and $k=\left(k_{1}, \ldots, k_{m+1}\right) \in \mathbb{N}^{m+1}$, a compact $m$-linear bi-parameter partial paraproduct $\mathbf{P}_{\mathcal{D}}^{1, k}$ of complexity $k$ is an operator of the form

$$
\mathbf{P}_{\mathcal{D}}^{1, k}(\vec{f}):=\sum_{\substack{Q=Q^{1} \times Q^{2} \in \mathcal{D} \\ j=1, \ldots, m+1}} \sum_{\substack{I_{j}^{1} \in \mathcal{D}_{k_{j}}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right) \\ j=1, \ldots, m+1}} a_{\left(I_{j}^{1}\right), Q} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\langle f_{j}, \widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{1}} \otimes \widetilde{h}_{j, Q^{2}}\right\rangle \widetilde{h}_{I_{m+1}^{1}} \otimes \widetilde{h}_{m+1, Q^{2}}
$$

where the functions $\widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{1}}$ and $\widetilde{h}_{j, Q^{2}}$ satisfy the following: there exist two different indices $j_{0}, j_{1} \in\{1, \ldots, m+1\}$ so that $\widetilde{h}_{I_{j_{0}}^{1}}=h_{I_{j_{0}}^{1}}, \widetilde{h}_{I_{j_{1}}^{1}}=h_{I_{j_{1}}^{1}}$, and $\widetilde{h}_{I_{j}^{1}} \in\left\{h_{I_{j}^{1}}^{0}, h_{I_{j}^{1}}\right\}$ for every $j \neq j_{0}, j_{1}$; there exists $j_{2} \in\{1, \ldots, m+1\}$ so that $\widetilde{h}_{j_{2}, Q^{2}}=h_{Q^{2}}$ and $\widetilde{h}_{j, Q^{2}}=\frac{\mathbf{1}_{Q^{2}}}{\left|Q^{2}\right|}$ for every $j \neq j_{2}$. Moreover, the coefficients $a_{\left(I_{j}^{1}\right), Q}$ satisfy

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{D}^{2}} \sup _{Q_{0}^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{\left|Q_{0}^{2}\right|} \sum_{\substack{Q^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2} \\ Q^{2} \subset Q_{0}^{2}}}\left|a_{\left(I_{j}^{1}\right), Q}\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \leq \mathcal{F}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right) \frac{\prod_{j=1}^{m+1}\left|I_{j}^{1}\right|^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\left|Q^{1}\right|^{m}}
$$

and

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{D}^{2}} \sup _{Q_{0}^{2} \in \mathcal{D}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{\left|Q_{0}^{2}\right|} \sum_{\substack{Q^{2} \notin \mathcal{D}^{2}(N) \\ Q^{2} \subset Q_{0}^{2}}}\left|a_{\left(I_{j}^{1}\right), Q}\right|^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \leq \mathcal{F}_{N}^{1} \frac{\prod_{j=1}^{m+1}\left|I_{j}^{1}\right|^{\frac{1}{2}}}{\left|Q^{1}\right|^{m}}
$$

with

$$
\mathcal{F}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right) \leq 1, \quad \mathcal{F}_{N}^{1} \leq 1, \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{N \rightarrow \infty}\left(\sup _{\mathcal{D}^{1}} \sup _{Q^{1} \notin \mathcal{D}^{1}(N)} \mathcal{F}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right)+\mathcal{F}_{N}^{1}\right)=0
$$

In the same way, we define an $m$-linear bi-parameter partial paraproduct $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}}^{1, k}$ of complexity $k$ if the coefficients $a_{\left(I_{j}^{1}\right), Q}$ just satisfy the first estimate with $\mathcal{F}^{1}\left(Q^{1}\right) \equiv 1$. Symmtrically, $\mathbf{P}_{\mathcal{D}}^{2, k}$ and $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{D}}^{2, k}$ are defined by interchanging parameters 1 and 2.

Definition 3.11. Given a dyadic grid $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}^{1} \times \mathcal{D}^{2}$, a compact $m$-linear bi-parameter full paraproduct takes the form

$$
\mathbf{F}_{\mathbf{a}}(\vec{f}):=\sum_{I=I^{1} \times I^{2} \in \mathcal{D}} a_{I} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\langle f_{j}, \bar{h}_{j, I^{1}} \otimes \bar{h}_{j, I^{2}}\right\rangle \bar{h}_{m+1, I^{1}} \otimes \bar{h}_{m+1, I^{2}}
$$

where there exist $j_{0}^{1}, j_{0}^{2} \in\{1, \ldots, m+1\}$ so that $\bar{h}_{j_{0}^{1}, I^{1}}=h_{I^{1}}, \bar{h}_{j_{0}^{2}, I^{2}}=h_{I^{2}}, \bar{h}_{j, I^{1}}=\frac{\mathbf{1}_{I^{1}}}{|I|^{1}}$ for every $j \neq j_{0}^{1}$, and $\bar{h}_{j, I^{2}}=\frac{\mathbf{1}_{I^{2}}}{|I|^{2}}$ for every $j \neq j_{0}^{2}$. Moreover, the coefficients $a_{I}$ satisfy

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{D}} \sup _{U} \frac{1}{|U|} \sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}: I \subset U}\left|a_{I}\right|^{2} \leq 1
$$

and

$$
\lim _{N \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\mathcal{D}} \sup _{U} \frac{1}{|U|} \sum_{I \notin \mathcal{D}(N): I \subset U}\left|a_{I}\right|^{2}=0
$$

where the supremum $\sup _{U}$ is taken over all open sets $U \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$ with $0<|U|<\infty$. Likewise, we define an $m$-linear bi-parameter full paraproduct $\mathbb{F}_{\mathbf{a}}$ if the coefficients $a_{I}$ just satisfy the first inequality.

Finally, having prepared conceptions above, we introduce the compact $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation of singular integrals.

Definition 3.12. Given an $m$-linear operator $T$, we say that $T$ admits a compact $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation if there exists a constant $C_{0}=C_{0}(T) \in$ $(0, \infty)$ so that for all compactly supported and bounded functions $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}, f_{m+1}$ on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$,

$$
\left\langle T(\vec{f}), f_{m+1}\right\rangle=C_{0} \mathbb{E}_{\omega} \sum_{k_{1}=0}^{\infty} \sum_{k_{2}=0}^{\infty} 2^{-k_{1} \frac{\delta_{1}}{\delta}} 2^{-k_{2} \frac{\delta_{2}}{\delta}}\left\langle\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k_{1}, k_{2}}(\vec{f}), f_{m+1}\right\rangle
$$

with

$$
\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k_{1}, k_{2}}=\sum_{i_{1}=0}^{k_{1}} \sum_{i_{2}=0}^{k_{2}} \mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k_{1}, k_{2}, i_{1}, i_{2}}
$$

where $\mathbf{S}_{\mathcal{D}_{\omega}}^{k_{1}, k_{2}, i_{1}, i_{2}}$ is a finite sum of compact $m$-linear bi-parameter shifts on $\mathcal{D}_{\omega}$ with complexity $\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m+1}\right)$, compact $m$-linear bi-parameter partial paraproducts on $\mathcal{D}_{\omega}$ with complexity $\left(v_{1}^{1}, \ldots, v_{m+1}^{1}\right)$ and $\left(v_{1}^{2}, \ldots, v_{m+1}^{2}\right)$, and compact $m$-linear biparameter full paraproducts on $\mathcal{D}_{\omega}$. In addition,

$$
u_{j}=\left(u_{j}^{1}, u_{j}^{2}\right), \quad u_{j}^{1}, v_{j}^{1} \leq k_{1}+1, \quad \text { and } \quad u_{j}^{2}, v_{j}^{2} \leq k_{2}+1, \quad \forall j=1, \ldots, m+1
$$

Analogously, we say that $T$ admits an $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation if compact $m$-linear bi-parameter shifts, compact $m$-linear bi-parameter partial paraproducts, and compact $m$-linear bi-parameter full paraproducts are replaced by $m$ linear bi-parameter shifts, $m$-linear bi-parameter partial paraproducts, and $m$-linear bi-parameter full paraproducts, respectively.

# 4. Auxiliary results 

In this section, we would like to give some useful estimates in order to show Theorem 1.4. For each $i=1,2$, let $\left(F_{1}^{i}, F_{2}^{i}, F_{3}^{i}\right) \in \mathscr{F}$ so that $F_{1}^{i}$ is increasing, $F_{2}^{i}$ and $F_{3}^{i}$ are decreasing. Define

$$
F^{i}\left(K^{i}, Q^{i}\right):=F_{1}^{i}\left(\ell\left(K^{i}\right)\right) \widetilde{F}_{2}^{i}\left(\ell\left(K^{i}\right)\right) \widetilde{F}_{3}^{i}\left(Q^{i}\right)
$$

for all cubes $K^{i}, Q^{i} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$, where

$$
\widetilde{F}_{2}^{i}(t):=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 2^{-k \theta} F_{2}^{i}\left(2^{-k} t\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \widetilde{F}_{3}^{i}\left(Q^{i}\right):=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} 2^{-k \theta} F_{3}^{i}\left(\operatorname{rd}\left(2^{k} Q^{i}, \mathbb{I}^{i}\right)\right)
$$

The auxiliary parameter $\theta \in(0,1)$ is harmless and small enough. Then it is not hard to verify

$$
\widetilde{F}_{3}^{i}\left(Q^{i}\right) \leq \widetilde{F}_{3}^{i}\left(\lambda Q^{i}\right) \leq C_{\lambda, \theta} \widetilde{F}_{3}^{i}\left(Q^{i}\right), \quad \forall \lambda \geq 1
$$

Since any dilation of functions in $\mathscr{F}, \mathscr{F}^{1}$, and $\mathscr{F}^{2}$ still belongs to the original space, we will often omit all universal constants appearing in the argument involving these functions.
4.1. Some integral estimates. The following three lemmas will be used frequently to establish the multilinear bi-parameter dyadic representation in Section 5.
Lemma 4.4. For each $i=1,2$, let $\left(F_{1}^{i}, F_{2}^{i}, F_{3}^{i}\right) \in \mathscr{F}$ satisfy that $F_{1}^{i}$ is increasing, $F_{2}^{i}$ and $F_{3}^{i}$ are decreasing. Let $I^{i}, J^{i}, K^{i}, Q^{i} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}$ be cubes such that $\ell\left(K^{i}\right) \leq$ $2 \ell\left(J^{i}\right)$ and $I^{i} \cup J^{i} \cup K^{i} \subset Q^{i}$. If $\max \left\{\mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, I^{i}\right), \mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, J^{i}\right)\right\}>2 \ell\left(K^{i}\right)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell\left(J^{i}\right)^{1-\gamma_{i}}$ and $\max \left\{\mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, I^{i}\right), \mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, J^{i}\right)\right\} \gtrsim 2 \ell\left(K^{i}\right)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell\left(Q^{i}\right)^{1-\gamma_{i}}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{P}_{i}\left(I^{i}, J^{i}, K^{i}\right) & :=\int_{J^{i}} \int_{I^{i}} \int_{K^{i}} \frac{F^{i}\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}\right) \ell\left(K^{i}\right)^{\delta_{i}}}{\left(\left|x_{i}-y_{i}\right|+\left|x_{i}-z_{i}\right|\right)^{2 n_{i}+\delta_{i}}} d x_{i} d y_{i} d z_{i} \\
& \lesssim\left[\frac{\ell\left(K^{i}\right)}{\ell\left(Q^{i}\right)}\right]^{\frac{\delta_{i}}{2}} F^{i}\left(K^{i}, Q^{i}\right) \frac{\left|I^{i}\right|\left|J^{i}\right|\left|K^{i}\right|}{\left|Q^{i}\right|^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where
$F^{i}\left(x_{i}, y_{i}, z_{i}\right):=F_{1}^{i}\left(\left|x_{i}-c_{K^{i}}\right|\right) F_{2}^{i}\left(\left|x_{i}-y_{i}\right|+\left|x_{i}-z_{i}\right|\right) F_{3}^{i}\left(1+\frac{\left|x_{i}+y_{i}\right|+\left|x_{i}+z_{i}\right|}{1+\left|x_{i}-y_{i}\right|+\left|x_{i}-z_{i}\right|}\right)$,
and $F^{i}\left(K^{i}, Q^{i}\right)$ is given in (4.1).
Proof. For all $x_{i} \in K^{i}, y_{i} \in I^{i}$, and $z_{i} \in J^{i}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\max & \left\{\left|x_{i}-y_{i}\right|,\left|x_{i}-z_{i}\right|\right\} \geq \max \left\{\mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, I^{i}\right), \mathrm{d}\left(K^{i}, J^{i}\right)\right\} \\
& >2 \ell\left(K^{i}\right)^{\gamma_{i}} \ell\left(J^{i}\right)^{1-\gamma_{i}} \geq 2^{\gamma_{i}} \ell\left(K^{i}\right) \geq 2^{1+\gamma_{i}}\left|x_{i}-c_{K^{i}}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
