\left.\left|\left\langle\Xi(\vec{f}), f_{m+1}\right\rangle\right| \lesssim|v|\left\|\left[\sum_{I \in \mathcal{D}} \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left(\left|f_{j}\right|\right\rangle\left.\right|^{2}\left\langle\left|\Delta_{I^{1}} f_{m+1}\right|\right\rangle_{I}^{2} \mathbf{1}_{I}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\|_{L^{1}}
$$

Having obtained (7.51), (7.56), (7.60), and (7.63), we apply [46, Theorem 5.5] to conlude

$$
\left.\left|\left\langle\Xi(\vec{f}), f_{m+1}\right\rangle\right| \lesssim|v| \prod_{j=1}^{m+1}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}}
$$

The proof is complete.

# 8. EXTRAPOLATION OF COMPACTNESS 

This section is devoted to proving Theorems 1.6 and 1.8, which have been used in Sections 6 and 7 respectively. After that, we will conclude Theorems 1.1 and 1.3 from Theorems $1.4-1.8$.
8.1. Interpolation of compactness. Let us first show Theorem 1.6 in the biparameter setting. Although the proof follows the scheme in [4], we present some details to clarify the main ingredients.

First, we give an interpolation of multiple weights below, which allows us to use interpolation of compactness to show extrapolation of compactness.
Lemma 8.1. Let $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ with $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m} \in(1, \infty]$ and $\frac{1}{s}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{s_{j}}$ with $s_{1}, \ldots, s_{m} \in[1, \infty]$. Assume that $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{s}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Then there exists $\theta \in(0,1)$ such that $\vec{u} \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where

$$
\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}, \quad u=\prod_{j=1}^{m} u_{j}, \quad w_{j}=u_{j}^{1-\theta} v_{j}^{\theta}, \quad \frac{1}{p_{j}}=\frac{1-\theta}{r_{j}}+\frac{\theta}{s_{j}}, \quad j=1, \ldots, m
$$

Proof. The proof heavily relies on the reverse Hölder inequality for $A_{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, which was proved by [20, p. 458] in the multi-parameter case. With this in hand, the proof is similar to that of [4, Lemma C.1].

Next, let us recall extrapolation of boundedness in the bi-parameter case [46, Theorem 3.12], which extends the one-parameter extrapolation result in [52].

Theorem 8.2. Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of $(m+1)$-tuples of non-negative functions. Assume that there exists some $\vec{q}=\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{m}\right) \in[1, \infty]^{m}$ such that for all $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{q}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$,

$$
\|f\|_{L^{q}(\mathbb{R}^{q})} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{q_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{q_{j}}\right)}, \quad \forall\left(f, f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right) \in \mathcal{F}
$$

where $\frac{1}{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{q_{j}}$ and $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$. Then for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$,

$$
\|f\|_{L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)}, \quad \forall\left(f, f_{1}, \ldots, f_{m}\right) \in \mathcal{F}
$$

where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.
Beyond that, the core of the proof of Theorem 1.6 is an interpolation of multilinear compact operators below, which determines the range of exponents. The greatest difficulty of Theorem 8.3 is to obtain the quasi-Banach range of exponents, for which we use compactness criterion Theorem 6.1.
Theorem 8.3. Let $0<p_{0}, q_{0}<\infty$ and $1 \leq p_{j}, q_{j} \leq \infty, j=1, \ldots, m$. Let $u_{0}^{q_{0}}, v_{0}^{q_{0}} \in$ $A_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $u_{j}, v_{j}$ be weights on $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}, j=1, \ldots, m$. Assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& T: L^{p_{1}}\left(u_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(u_{m}^{p_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p_{0}}\left(u_{0}^{q_{0}}\right) \text { boundedly, } \\
& T: L^{q_{1}}\left(v_{1}^{q_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{q_{m}}\left(v_{m}^{q_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{q_{0}}\left(v_{0}^{q_{0}}\right) \text { compactly. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Then,

$$
T: L^{r_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{r_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{r_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{r_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{r_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{q_{0}}\right) \text { compactly }
$$

where

$$
\theta \in(0,1), \quad w_{j}=u_{j}^{1-\theta} v_{j}^{\theta}, \quad \frac{1}{r_{j}}=\frac{1-\theta}{p_{j}}+\frac{\theta}{q_{j}}, \quad j=0,1, \ldots, m
$$

Proof. Let $u_{0}^{p_{0}}, v_{0}^{q_{0}} \in A_{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Then $u_{0}^{p_{0}} \in A_{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ for some $s \in(1, \infty)$. Picking $0<a<\min \left\{p_{0} / s, 1\right\}$, we see that $u_{0}^{p_{0}} \in A_{s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \subset A_{p_{0} / a}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Note that for any $\rho>0$,

$$
\left(f_{B_{\mathcal{S}}(0, \rho)}\left|\tau_{y} f(x)-f(x)\right|^{a} d y\right)^{\frac{1}{a}} \lesssim M_{\mathcal{R}}\left(|f|^{a}\right)(x)^{\frac{1}{a}}+|f(x)|
$$

which, along with the weighted boundedness of $M_{\mathcal{R}}$ (cf. [20, p. 453]) and (8.4), implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\left(f_{B_{\mathcal{S}}(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y} T-T\right)(\vec{f})|^{a} d y\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right|\right|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(u_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|M_{\mathcal{R}}\left(|T(\vec{f})|^{a}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(u_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)}+\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(u_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(u_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(u_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\varepsilon>0$. By (8.5) and Theorem 6.1, there exist $A_{0}=A_{0}(\varepsilon)>0$ and $\rho_{0}=\rho_{0}(\varepsilon)>$ 0 such that for all $A \geq A_{0}$ and $0<\rho<\rho_{0}$,

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{q_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{q_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{q_{0}}\left(v_{0}^{q_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{1}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{q_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f}) \mathbf{1}_{B_{a}(0, A)^{c}}\|_{L^{q_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{q_{0}}\right)} \leq \varepsilon \\
& \sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{q_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\left\|\left(f_{B a(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y} T-T\right)(\vec{f})|^{a} d y\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{q_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{q_{0}}\right)} \leq \varepsilon\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{1}>0$ is an absolute constant. Moreover, by (8.4) and (8.7), for any $A>0$ and $\rho>0$,

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}
$$

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f}) \mathbf{1}_{B_{a}(0, A)^{c}}\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}
$$

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\left\|\left(f_{B a(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y} T-T\right)(\vec{f})|^{a} d y\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{p_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{p_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}\right.
$$

where $C_{0}>0$ is an absolute constant. Thus, interpolating between (8.8) and (8.11) gives

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{r_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{r_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}^{1-\theta} C_{1}^{\theta}
$$

Similarly, by (8.9) and (8.12),

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\|T(\vec{f}) \mathbf{1}_{B_{a}(0, A)^{c}}\|_{L^{r_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{r_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}^{1-\theta} \varepsilon^{\theta}
$$

for any $A \geq A_{0}$. Moreover, by interpolation on mixed-norm Lebesgue spaces (cf. [5, Theorem 3.5]), (8.10) and (8.13) imply

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)} \leq 1}}\left\|\left(f_{B a(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y} T-T\right)(\vec{f})|^{a} d y\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{r_{0}}\left(w_{0}^{r_{0}}\right)} \leq C_{0}^{1-\theta} \varepsilon^{\theta}\right.
$$

for any $0<\rho<\rho_{0}$. Therefore, (8.6) follows from (8.14)-(8.16) and Theorem 6.1.
8.2. Proof of Theorem 1.6. Fix $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ with $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}>0$. Let $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. Recall that the assumption (a):

$$
T: L^{p_{1}}\left(u_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(u_{m}^{p_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(u^{p}\right) \text { compactly }
$$

where $\vec{u} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Then by Lemma 8.1 applied to $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $\vec{u} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, there exists $\theta \in(0,1)$ such that $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{s}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where

$$
\frac{1}{s}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{s_{j}}, \quad v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}, \quad w_{j}=v_{j}^{1-\theta} u_{j}^{\theta}, \quad \frac{1}{r_{j}}=\frac{1-\theta}{s_{j}}+\frac{\theta}{p_{j}}, \quad j=1, \ldots, m
$$

In view of Theorem 8.2, the assumption (b) implies

$$
T: L^{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{1}^{t_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{\sigma_{m}}\left(\sigma_{m}^{t_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{t}\left(\sigma^{t}\right) \text { boundedly, }
$$

for all $\vec{t}=\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{\sigma}=\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{t}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{t_{j}}>0$ and $\sigma=\prod_{j=1}^{m} \sigma_{j}$. Then (8.19) applied to $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{s}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ yields

$$
T: L^{s_{1}}\left(v_{1}^{s_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{v_{m}}\left(v_{m}^{s_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right) \text { boundedly. }
$$

Hence, it follows from (8.17), (8.18), (8.20), and Theorem 8.3 that

$$
T: L^{r_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{r_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{r_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{r_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{r}\left(w^{r}\right) \text { compactly. }
$$

This completes the proof of Theorem 1.6.
8.3. Extrapolation for commutators. Before proving Theorem 1.8, let us present an extrapolation for commutators in the spirit of [1].
Theorem 8.21. Let $T$ be an m-linear operator. Assume that there exists some $\vec{q}=$ $\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{m}\right) \in[1, \infty]^{m}$ such that for all $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{q}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$,

$$
\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{q}\left(v^{q}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{q_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{q_{j}}\right)}
$$

where $\frac{1}{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{q_{j}}$ and $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$. Then for any $\alpha \in \mathbb{N}^{m}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in$ $\operatorname{bmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m}$,

$$
\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\|_{L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|b_{j}\right\|_{\operatorname{bmo}}^{n_{j}}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)}
$$

for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$.
Proof. Fix $\alpha \in \mathbb{N}^{m}$ and $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in \operatorname{bmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m}$. Choose $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in$ $(1, \infty)^{m}$ so that $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}<1$. In view of Theorem 8.2, the hypothesis (8.22) implies that

$$
\|T(\vec{f})\|_{L^{r}\left(u^{r}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(u_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)}
$$

for all $\vec{u}=\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $u=\prod_{j=1}^{m} u_{j}$.
In the bi-parameter setting, recall the reverse Hölder inequality [20, p. 458] and the John-Nirenberg inequality [29, Section 5.6]. Using these two inequalities, as argued in [1, p. 84], one can show that for any $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, there holds

$$
\vec{u}=\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right):=\left(v_{1} e^{-\operatorname{Re}\left(z_{1}\right) b_{1}}, \ldots, v_{m} e^{-\operatorname{Re}\left(z_{m}\right) b_{m}}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)
$$

whenever $\left|z_{j}\right| \leq \eta_{j}$ for some $\eta_{j}>0, j=1, \ldots, m$. Then following the proof of [1, Theorem 4.13], we apply the Cauchy integral trick, (8.24), and (8.25) to deduce that

$$
\left\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right\|_{L^{r}\left(v^{p}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|b_{j}\right\|_{\mathrm{bmo}}^{\alpha_{j}}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)}
$$

for all $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$. Therefore, it follows from (8.26) and Theorem 8.2 that

$$
\left\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right\|_{L^{p}\left(w^{p}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|b_{j}\right\|_{\mathrm{bmo}}^{\alpha_{j}}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)}
$$

for all $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. This justifies (8.23).
8.4. Proof of Theorem 1.8. Let $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ with $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}>0$. Let $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. Let $\varepsilon>0$ be an arbitrary number. By the assumption (a), there exists some $\rho_{0}=\rho_{0}(\varepsilon)>0$ such that

$$
\left\|\left[\int_{B_{\vec{a}}(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right)[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right|^{\text {a }_{0}} d y\right]^{\frac{1}{s_{0}}}\right\|_{L^{p}\left(u^{p}\right)} \leq \varepsilon \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{p_{j}}\left(u_{j}^{p_{j}}\right)}
$$

for all $0<\rho<\rho_{0}$ and for some $a_{0} \in(0,1]$. Recall that $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$ and $\vec{u} \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Then invoking Lemma 8.1, one can find some $\theta \in(0,1)$ such that $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{s}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where

$$
\frac{1}{s}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{s_{j}}, \quad v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}, \quad w_{j}=v_{j}^{1-\theta} u_{j}^{\theta}, \quad \frac{1}{r_{j}}=\frac{1-\theta}{s_{j}}+\frac{\theta}{p_{j}}, \quad j=1, \ldots, m
$$

On the other hand, by the assumption (b) and Theorem 8.21,

$$
[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}: L^{t_{1}}\left(\sigma_{1}^{t_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{\sigma_{m}}\left(\sigma_{m}^{t_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{t}\left(\sigma^{t}\right) \text { boundedly, }
$$

for all $\vec{t}=\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{\sigma}=\left(\sigma_{1}, \ldots, \sigma_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{t}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{t_{j}}>0$ and $\sigma=\prod_{j=1}^{m} \sigma_{j}$. Hence, applying (8.29) to $\vec{v} \in A_{\vec{s}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, we obtain

$$
\left\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{s_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{s_{j}}\right)}
$$

where the implicit constant is independent of $\vec{f}$. In light of Theorem 2.13, there holds $v^{s} \in A_{m s}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \subset A_{s / a}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $0<a \leq \min \left\{a_{0}, \frac{1}{m}\right\}$. Observe that for any $\rho>0$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\int_{B_{\vec{a}}(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right) f(x)\right|^{a} d y\right]^{\frac{1}{a}}} \\
& \lesssim M_{\mathfrak{R}}\left(|f|^{a}\right)(x)^{\frac{1}{a}}+M_{n_{1}}\left(\left|f_{x_{2}}\right|^{a}\right)\left(x_{1}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}+M_{n_{2}}\left(\left|f_{x_{1}}\right|^{a}\right)\left(x_{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}+|f(x)|
\end{aligned}
$$

which, along with the weighted boundedness of $M_{\mathcal{R}}$ (cf. [20, p. 453]), (6.11), and (8.30), implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\left[\int_{B_{\vec{a}}(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right)[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right|^{a} d y\right]^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)} \\
& \lesssim\left\|M_{\mathcal{R}}\left(\left|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})]^{a}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)}+\left\|M_{n_{1}}\left(\left|\left([\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f}))_{x_{2}}\right|^{a}\right)\left(x_{1}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)}\right. \\
& \left.\quad+\left\|M_{n_{2}}\left(\left|\left([\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f}))_{x_{1}}\right|^{a}\right)\left(x_{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)}+\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)}\right. \\
& \lesssim\|[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\|_{L^{s}\left(v^{s}\right)} \lesssim \prod_{j=1}^{m}\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{s_{j}}\left(v_{j}^{s_{j}}\right)},
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $\rho>0$. As a consequence of (8.27) (which holds for $a$ in place of $a_{0}$ ), (8.28), (8.31), and [5, Theorem 3.5], we conclude that

$$
\sup _{\substack{\left\|f_{j}\right\|_{L^{r_{j}}\left(w_{j}^{r_{j}}\right)} \leq 1 \\\left.\leq 1\right\|}}\left\|\left[\int_{B_{\vec{a}}(0, \rho)}\left|\left(\tau_{y}-\tau_{y_{1}}-\tau_{y_{2}}+I\right)[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}(\vec{f})\right|^{a} d y\right]^{\frac{1}{a}}\right\|_{L^{r}\left(w^{r}\right)} \leq C_{0}^{1-\theta} \varepsilon^{\theta},
$$

for all $0<\rho<\rho_{0}$. This and (8.29) show Theorem 1.8.
8.5. Proof of Theorem 1.1. Having established fundamental estimates above, let us demonstrate Theorem 1.1.

Pick $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty)^{m}$ such that $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}} \in(0,1)$. Let $\vec{u}=$ $\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{p}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$. Theorem 1.4 asserts that $T$ admits a compact $m$ linear bi-parameter dyadic representation. This, along with Theorem 1.5, gives

$$
T: L^{p_{1}}\left(u_{1}^{p_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(u_{m}^{p_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{p}\left(u^{p}\right) \text { compactly }
$$

where we have used an $m$-linear bi-parameter version of [4, Lemma 4.52]. Moreover, the hypotheses (H1)-(H5) imply that $T$ is an $m$-linear bi-parameter CalderónZygmund operator, which together with [46, Theorem 1.2] yields

$$
T: L^{q_{1}}\left(v_{1}^{q_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{q_{m}}\left(v_{m}^{q_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{q}\left(v^{q}\right) \text { boundedly }
$$

for all $\vec{q}=\left(q_{1}, \ldots, q_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and for all $\vec{v}=\left(v_{1}, \ldots, v_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{q}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{q}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{q_{j}}>0$ and $v=\prod_{j=1}^{m} v_{j}$. Accordingly, invoking Theorem 1.6, (8.32), and (8.33), we conclude that

$$
T: L^{r_{1}}\left(w_{1}^{r_{1}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{r_{m}}\left(w_{m}^{r_{m}}\right) \rightarrow L^{r}\left(w^{r}\right) \text { compactly }
$$

for all $\vec{r}=\left(r_{1}, \ldots, r_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty]^{m}$ and $\vec{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{m}\right) \in A_{\vec{r}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)$, where $\frac{1}{r}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{r_{j}}>0$ and $w=\prod_{j=1}^{m} w_{j}$. The proof is complete.
8.6. Proof of Theorem 1.3. Let $\boldsymbol{b}=\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{m}\right) \in \operatorname{cmo}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)^{m}$ and $T$ be an $m$-linear bi-parameter Calderón-Zygmund operator. Then in view of Theorem 1.8

and the weighted boundedness (8.33), to obtain the mean continuity of $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ on weighted Lebesgue spaces, it suffices to show that

$$
[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}} \text { is mean continuous from }
$$

$$
L^{p_{1}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \times \cdots \times L^{p_{m}}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right) \text { to } L^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}} \times \mathbb{R}^{n_{2}}\right)
$$

for some $\vec{p}=\left(p_{1}, \ldots, p_{m}\right) \in(1, \infty)^{m}$ with $\frac{1}{p}=\sum_{j=1}^{m} \frac{1}{p_{j}} \in(0,1)$.
By [46, Proposition 7.7], $T$ admits an $m$-linear bi-parameter dyadic representation (cf. Definition 3.12). This and Theorem 1.7 imply (8.34) as desired.

# Appendix A. Uchiyama's characterization of CMO space 

For the convenience of the reader, we present all details in the proof of the characterization of CMO although the central case $p=1$ was given in [65, Lemma 3]. It is helpful to understand the precise structure of $\operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.

Theorem A.1. Let $p \in[1, \infty)$ and $f \in L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. Then $f \in \mathrm{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ if and only if $f \in \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and the following properties hold:

$$
\gamma_{1}(f):=\lim _{r \rightarrow 0} \sup _{\substack{Q \in \mathcal{Q} \\ \ell(Q) \geq r}} \mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q)=0
$$

$$
\gamma_{2}(f):=\lim _{r \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\substack{Q \in \mathcal{Q} \\ \ell(Q) \geq r}} \mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q)=0
$$

$$
\gamma_{3}(f):=\lim _{r \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\substack{Q \in \mathcal{Q} \\ \mathrm{d}(Q, 0) \geq r}} \mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q)=0
$$

where $\mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q):=\left[\oint_{Q}|f(x)-\langle f\rangle_{Q}\right]^{p} d x]^{\frac{1}{p}}$.
Proof. Let $f \in \operatorname{CMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and $\varepsilon>0$. Then there exists $f_{\varepsilon} \in \mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ such that $\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \leq \varepsilon$, which gives $\|f\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \leq\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}}+\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \leq \varepsilon+2\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{\infty}}<\infty$. Since $f_{\varepsilon}$ is uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, there exists some $r_{\varepsilon}>0$ so that

$$
\sup _{|x-y| \leq r_{\varepsilon}}\left|f_{\varepsilon}(x)-f_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \leq \varepsilon
$$

By definition, we have

$$
\mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q) \leq \mathcal{O}_{p}\left(f-f_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right)+\mathcal{O}_{p}\left(f_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right)
$$

which implies

$$
\mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q) \leq\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}}+\sup _{x, y \in Q}\left|f_{\varepsilon}(x)-f_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \leq 2 \varepsilon, \quad \forall Q: \ell(Q) \leq r_{\varepsilon}
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q) \leq\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}}+2\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{p}}|Q|^{-\frac{1}{p}} \leq 2 \varepsilon, \quad \forall Q:|Q| \geq 2^{p} \varepsilon^{-p}\left\|f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{p}}^{p}
$$

Let $\operatorname{supp}\left(f_{\varepsilon}\right) \subset B\left(0, A_{\varepsilon} / 2\right)$ for some $A_{\varepsilon}>0$. If $\mathrm{d}(Q, 0) \geq A_{\varepsilon}$, then $Q \cap \operatorname{supp}\left(f_{\varepsilon}\right)=\varnothing$ and $\mathcal{O}_{p}\left(f_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right)=0$. This along with (A.6) yields

$$
\mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q) \leq\left\|f-f_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}}+0 \leq \varepsilon, \quad \forall Q: \mathrm{d}(Q, 0) \geq A_{\varepsilon}
$$

Hence, (A.7)-(A.9) imply $\gamma_{1}(f)=\gamma_{2}(f)=\gamma_{3}(f)=0$.
To show the converse, it suffices to treat the case $p=1$ because $\mathcal{O}(f ; Q):=$ $\mathcal{O}_{1}(f ; Q) \leq \mathcal{O}_{p}(f ; Q)$ for any $p \in[1, \infty)$. Let $f \in \operatorname{BMO}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ with $\gamma_{i}(f)=0, i=1,2,3$. Let $\varepsilon>0$ be an arbitrary number. It is enough to show that there exist $f_{\varepsilon} \in \mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ and a simple function $g_{\varepsilon}$ such that

$$
\left\|f_{\varepsilon}-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \lesssim \varepsilon \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

For any $r>0$, let $Q(r)$ denote the cube centered at the origin with sidelength $2 r$. By the condition $\gamma_{1}(f)=\gamma_{3}(f)=0$, there exists some $j_{0}=j_{0}(\varepsilon) \geq 2$ such that

$$
\sup _{\ell(Q) \leq 2^{-j_{0}}} \mathcal{O}(f ; Q)+\sup _{\mathrm{d}(Q, 0) \geq 2^{j_{0}}} \mathcal{O}(f ; Q) \leq \varepsilon
$$

Moreover, the fact $\gamma_{2}(f)=0$ implies that for some $j_{1}=j_{1}(\varepsilon)>3 j_{0}$,

$$
\sup _{\ell(Q) \geq 2^{j_{1}}} \mathcal{O}(f ; Q) \leq 2^{-2 n j_{0}} \varepsilon
$$

Let $\mathcal{D}$ be the standard dyadic grid on $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Define $\mathcal{F}=\bigcup_{j \geq j_{0}} \mathcal{F}_{j}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{F}_{j_{0}}:=\left\{Q \in \mathcal{D}: Q \subset \overline{Q\left(2^{j_{0}}\right)}, \ell(Q)=2^{-j_{0}}\right\} \\
& \mathcal{F}_{j}:=\left\{Q \in \mathcal{D}: Q \subset \overline{Q\left(2^{j}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j-1}\right)}, \ell(Q)=2^{-j_{0}+j-j_{0}}\right\}, \quad \forall j>j_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Observe that $\mathcal{F}$ is a collection of disjoint dyadic cubes, and for any $x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$, there exists a unique cube $Q_{x} \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $x \in Q_{x}$. Then by (A.10),

$$
\sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}} \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q_{x}\right) \leq \varepsilon
$$

Now choose a non-negative function $\varphi \in \mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ with $\operatorname{supp}(\varphi) \subset B(0,1 / 2)$ and $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}} \varphi d x=1$. Define $\varphi_{j_{0}}(x):=2^{n j_{0}} \varphi\left(2^{j_{0}} x\right)$,

$$
g_{\varepsilon}(x)= \begin{cases}\langle f\rangle_{Q_{x}}, & x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \\ \langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}, & x \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
f_{\varepsilon}=\varphi_{j_{0}} *\left(g_{\varepsilon}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\right)
$$

Note that $g_{\varepsilon}$ is a simple function and $f_{\varepsilon} \in \mathscr{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$. In addition, for any $x, y \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ with $|x-y| \leq 2^{-j_{0}-1}$, it must hold $\bar{Q}_{x} \cap \bar{Q}_{y} \neq \varnothing$. Then by Lemma A.22,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|f_{\varepsilon}-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} & =\left\|\varphi_{j_{0}} * g_{\varepsilon}-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \leq 2\left\|\varphi_{j_{0}} * g_{\varepsilon}-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{L^{\infty}} \\
& \leq 2\left\|\varphi_{j_{0}}\right\|_{L^{1}} \sup _{|x-y| \leq 2^{-j_{0}-1}}\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \lesssim \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Let us next verify $\left\|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\mathrm{BMO}} \lesssim \varepsilon$. Let $Q$ be an arbitrary cube in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. We are going to demonstrate

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

where the implicit constant depends only on the dimension $n$. First, in the case $Q \cap Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)=\varnothing$, we invoke (A.10) and Lemma A. 22 to obtain

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \leq \mathcal{O}(f ; Q)+\sup _{x, y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

Second, to consider the case $Q \subset Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$, set $\ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right):=\max \left\{\ell\left(Q_{x}\right): Q_{x} \cap Q \neq \emptyset\right\}$. In the scenario $\ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right) \leq 4 \ell(Q)$, observe that

$$
\oint_{Q_{x}}\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right| d y \lesssim \varepsilon, \quad \forall x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)
$$

Indeed, for all $x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$ and $y \in Q_{x}$, we have $y \in Q_{y}=Q_{x} \subset Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$ and $g_{\varepsilon}(y)=$ $\langle f\rangle_{Q_{y}}=\langle f\rangle_{Q_{x}}$, which imply $\oint_{Q_{x}}\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right| d y=\mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q_{x}\right) \leq \varepsilon$, provided (A.12). The condition $Q_{x} \cap Q \neq \emptyset$ and $\ell\left(Q_{x}\right) \leq 4 \ell(Q)$ implies $Q_{x} \subset 9 Q$. Thus, by (A.14) and the disjointness of $\left\{Q_{x}\right\}$,

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \leq 2 \oint_{Q}\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right| d y \leq \sum_{Q_{x} \cap Q \neq \varnothing} \frac{2}{|Q|} \int_{Q_{x}}\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right| d y \lesssim \frac{|9 Q|}{|Q|} \varepsilon \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

In the setting $\ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right)>4 \ell(Q)$, note that

$$
Q \cap Q\left(2^{j_{0}}\right) \neq \varnothing \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \ell(Q)<2^{-j_{0}}
$$

Indeed, if $x_{0} \in Q\left(2^{j_{0}+1}\right)$, then $\ell(Q)<\ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right) / 4 \leq 2^{-j_{0}+1} / 4<2^{-j_{0}}$; if $x_{0} \in Q\left(2^{j}\right) \backslash$ $Q\left(2^{j-1}\right)$ for some $j \geq j_{0}+2$, then $Q_{x_{0}} \subset Q\left(2^{j}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j-1}\right)$ and $\ell(Q)<\ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right) / 4=$ $2^{j-2 j_{0}-2}$, which contradicts the fact $\ell(Q) \geq 2^{j-1}-2^{j_{0}}$ because $Q \cap Q_{x_{0}} \neq \emptyset, Q \cap$ $Q\left(2^{j_{0}}\right) \neq \varnothing$, and $2^{j-1}-2^{j_{0}}-2^{j-2 j_{0}-2}=2^{j-1}\left[1-2^{-\left(j-j_{0}-2\right)-1}-2^{-2 j_{0}-1}\right]>0$. Consequently, it follows from (A.10) and (A.15) that

$$
\mathcal{O}(f ; Q) \leq \varepsilon
$$

In addition, for any $x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$ with $\bar{Q}_{x} \cap \bar{Q}_{x_{0}} \neq \emptyset$, there holds $2 \ell(Q) \leq \ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right) / 2 \leq$ $\ell\left(Q_{x}\right) \leq 2 \ell\left(Q_{x_{0}}\right)$. This indicates

$$
Q \subset \bigcup_{x \in \Lambda} Q_{x} \quad \text { with } \quad Q_{x} \cap Q \neq \varnothing \quad \text { and } \quad \# \Lambda \lesssim 1
$$

Then for all $x, y \in Q$, one can a sequence $\left\{x_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N_{0}} \subset \Lambda$ such that $\bar{Q}_{x_{i}} \cap \bar{Q}_{x_{i+1}} \neq \emptyset$, $i=0,1, \ldots, N_{0}=N_{0}(x, y)$, where $x_{0}:=x$ and $x_{N_{0}+1}:=y$. Hence, by Lemma A.22,

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \leq \sup _{x, y \in Q}\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \leq \sup _{x, y \in Q} \sum_{i=0}^{N_{0}}\left|g_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{i}\right)-g_{\varepsilon}\left(x_{i+1}\right)\right| \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

which along with (A.16) yields

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \leq \mathcal{O}(f ; Q)+\mathcal{O}\left(g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

Finally, to treat the case $Q \cap Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right) \neq \emptyset$ and $Q \cap Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)^{c} \neq \emptyset$, let $j_{2}>j_{1}$ be the smallest integer satisfying $Q \subset Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)$. Then,

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \lesssim \mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right) \leq \mathscr{I}_{1}+\mathscr{I}_{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{I}_{1} & :=\frac{1}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right|} \int_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\left|\left(f-g_{\varepsilon}\right)-\left\langle f-g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right| d y \\
\mathscr{I}_{2} & :=\frac{1}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right|} \int_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\left|\left(f-g_{\varepsilon}\right)-\left\langle f-g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right| d y
\end{aligned}
$$

We split

$$
\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}=\left[1-\frac{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right|}\right]\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}+\frac{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right|}\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}
$$

which together with (A.10) implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{I}_{1} & \leq \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right)+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}-\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq \varepsilon+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}-\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq \varepsilon+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right|+\left\langle\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)} \\
& \leq \varepsilon+2^{n} \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right)+\left\langle\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)} \\
& \leq\left(1+2^{n}\right) \varepsilon+\left\langle\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{I}_{2} \leq & \frac{1}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)\right|} \int_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\left|\left(f-g_{\varepsilon}\right)-\left\langle f-g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right| d y \\
\leq & \left.\left.\langle | f-g_{\varepsilon}|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}+2^{-\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) n}\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}-\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right|\right. \\
\leq & \left.\left.\langle | f-g_{\varepsilon}|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}-\left\langle g_{\varepsilon}\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}\right|\right. \\
& +2^{-\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) n}\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\right| \\
& \lesssim \varepsilon+\left.\left.\langle | f-g_{\varepsilon}|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}+2^{-\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) n}\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\right|\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality (A.12) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.\left.\langle | f-g_{\varepsilon}|\right\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right. & \leq \sum_{Q_{x} \subset Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)} \frac{1}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|} \int_{Q_{x}}\left|f-g_{\varepsilon}\right| d y \\
& =\sum_{Q_{x} \subset Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)} \frac{\left|Q_{x}\right|}{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|} \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q_{x}\right) \leq \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

and (A.11) leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{2}}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{j_{1}<j \leq j_{2}}\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j-1}\right)}\right|+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{j_{1} \leq j \leq j_{2}} 2^{n} \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q\left(2^{j}\right)\right) \lesssim\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Now gathering (A.17)-(A.21), we conclude

$$
\mathcal{O}\left(f-g_{\varepsilon} ; Q\right) \lesssim \varepsilon+\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) 2^{-\left(j_{2}-j_{1}\right) n} \varepsilon \leq 2 \varepsilon
$$

This completes the proof of (A.13).
Lemma A.22. If $x, y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$ or $\bar{Q}_{x} \cap \bar{Q}_{y} \neq \emptyset$, then

$$
\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| \lesssim \varepsilon
$$

Proof. We first deal with the case $x, y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$. If $x, y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$, then $g_{\varepsilon}(x)=g_{\varepsilon}(y)$. If $x, y \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$, we have $Q_{x} \cup Q_{y} \subset Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right), \ell\left(Q_{x}\right)=\ell\left(Q_{y}\right)=2^{j_{1}-2 j_{0}}$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right|=\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q_{x}}-\langle f\rangle_{Q_{y}}\right| \\
& \leq\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q_{x}}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right|+\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q_{y}}-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq \oint_{Q_{x}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right|+\oint_{Q_{y}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq\left[\frac{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|}{\left|Q_{x}\right|}+\frac{\left|Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right|}{\left|Q_{y}\right|}\right] \oint_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right| \\
& =2^{2 n j_{0}+1} \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right) \lesssim \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where (A.11) was used in the last step. If $x \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$ and $y \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$, then the inequality (A.11) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right|=\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}-\langle f\rangle_{Q_{y}}\right| \\
& \leq \oint_{Q_{y}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right|+\oint_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq\left(2^{(2 j_{0}+1) n}+2^{n}\right) \mathcal{O}\left(f ; Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)\right) \lesssim \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

A similar argument holds in the case $x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$ and $y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right)$.
Let us turn to the situation $\bar{Q}_{x} \cap \bar{Q}_{y} \neq \varnothing$. The case $x, y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$ has been shown above. If $x \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$ and $y \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$, then the condition $\bar{Q}_{x} \cap \bar{Q}_{y} \neq \varnothing$ implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}}\right) \backslash Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right), \quad 2 \ell\left(Q_{x}\right)=\ell\left(Q_{y}\right)=2^{j_{1}-2 j_{0}}, \quad Q_{x} \subset 2 Q_{y}, \quad \text { and } \\
& \mathrm{d}\left(2 Q_{y}, 0\right)=2^{j_{1}-1}-\ell\left(Q_{y}\right) / 2=2^{j_{0}} \cdot 2^{j_{1}-3 j_{0}-1}\left(2^{2 j_{0}}-1\right) \geq 2^{j_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which together with (A.10) leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|g_{\varepsilon}(x)-g_{\varepsilon}(y)\right| & =\left|\langle f\rangle_{Q_{x}}-\langle f\rangle_{Q_{y}}\right| \leq \oint_{Q_{x}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{2 Q_{y}}\right|+\oint_{Q_{y}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{2 Q_{y}}\right| \\
& \leq\left[\frac{\left|2 Q_{y}\right|}{\left|Q_{x}\right|}+\frac{\left|2 Q_{y}\right|}{\left|Q_{y}\right|}\right] \oint_{2 Q_{y}}\left|f-\langle f\rangle_{2 Q_{y}}\right|=\left(4^{n}+2^{n}\right) \mathcal{O}\left(f, 2 Q_{y}\right) \lesssim \varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Symmetrically, one can handle the case $x \notin Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$ and $y \in Q\left(2^{j_{1}-1}\right)$.

abstract:
We develop the compactness theory of multilinear singular integrals on
product spaces using a modern point of view. The first main result is a compact
$T1$ theorem for multilinear Calder\'{o}n--Zygmund operators on product spaces.
More specifically, we prove that a multilinear singular integral operator $T$
on product spaces can be extended to a compact multilinear operator from
$L^{p_1}(w_1^{p_1}) \times \cdots \times L^{p_m}(w_m^{p_m})$ to $L^p(w^p)$ for
all exponents $\frac1p = \sum_{j=1}^m \frac{1}{p_j}>0$ with $p_1, \ldots, p_m
\in (1, \infty]$ and for all weights $\vec{w} \in A_{\vec{p}}(\mathbb{R}^{n_1}
\times \mathbb{R}^{n_2})$ if the following hypotheses are satisfied: (H1) $T$
admits a compact full kernel representation, (H2) $T$ admits a compact partial
kernel representation, (H3) $T$ satisfies the weak compactness property, (H4)
$T$ satisfies the diagonal $\mathrm{CMO}$ condition, and (H5) $T$ satisfies the
product $\mathrm{CMO}$ condition. This is a multilinear compact extension of
Journ\'{e}'s $T1$ theorem on product spaces. The second main result establishes
the mean continuity of commutators $[\boldsymbol{b}, T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$
on weighted Lebesgue spaces as above, which can be viewed as a substitution of
compactness because the compactness of $[\boldsymbol{b},
T]_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}$ is equivalent to $\boldsymbol{b} \equiv
\text{constant}$ when $T$ is a non-degenerate bi-parameter singular integral.
Our main tools include multilinear bi-parameter dyadic representation,
multilinear extrapolation, multilinear interpolation, and Kolmogorov--Riesz
compactness criterion.
